business.start.para: The SPEAKER (Hon. David Hawker) took the chair at 2 p.m. and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —I remind the House that the address-in-reply will be presented to His Excellency the Governor-General at Government House at 6.30 this evening. Today’s sitting will be suspended at 6 p.m. and the chair will be resumed at 8 p.m. I shall be glad if the mover, the member for Greenway, and the seconder, the member for Stirling, together with other honourable members, will accompany me to present the address.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
talker.role: Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr HOWARD

talk.start.para: —I inform the House that the Minister for Health and Ageing will be absent from question time today due to an important personal commitment. The Minister for Ageing will answer questions on his behalf.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister had a discussion with the member for Wentworth regarding the member’s taxation proposals? If not, does he plan to do so or will he ignore the member for Wentworth? Has the Prime Minister arranged for meetings between the member for Wentworth and the Treasurer to reconcile their views on tax?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
talker.role: Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr HOWARD

talk.start.para: —I have numerous discussions with the member for Wentworth. As it happens, we had a discussion not seven minutes ago about taxation. He was showing me a letter he was writing to the Sydney Morning Herald to correct a misreporting of his views. I will let the Leader of the Opposition in on another secret: I had dinner last night with the member for Wentworth. I hasten to assure you that the member for Indi was present as well. But do not worry—it was a very kosher gathering because the member for Corangamite was there to keep us in order and there were sundry other colleagues there. The member for Kingston was there too, doing that sound South Australian commentary, and there were numbers of others of my colleagues.

answer.para: Can I say to the Leader of the Opposition that all of us on this side of the House are very proud of the way in which taxation has been reduced under this government. We are very proud of the fact that further taxation cuts will come into operation, as legislated following last year’s budget, on 1 July this year. I am very proud of the fact that, as a result of the tax and other reforms that this government has undertaken, the disposable income of an average production worker in Australia is the second lowest in the OECD area.
Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am sorry, Mr Speaker‌—the second highest in the OECD area. I am proud of the fact that the taxation levels in this country are the eighth lowest in the OECD area. I am also proud of the fact that this government in the last budget introduced changes to our welfare and taxation systems that have greatly enhanced the position of Australian families, not least those on low and middle incomes.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House of the government’s reaction to the latest events in Lebanon and of their implications for the Middle East?

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr DOWNER

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Greenway for her interest in this issue. Yesterday was the one-month anniversary of Rafik Hariri’s assassination. There was another very powerful demonstration of people power with a simply massive turnout at a peaceful demonstration in Beirut. Lebanese, British and French media reports estimate that the turnout was around one million people. The demands of the people in the street were the same as I articulated a month ago: the perpetrators of this vile act of terrorism must be brought to justice. Also, there is no doubt that Syria must implement Security Council resolution 1559 and fully withdraw from Lebanon, and we are pleased to see that beginning to happen.

answer.para: What is happening in Lebanon is part of a broader trend in the Middle East. People of the Middle East are standing up to terrorism, violence, intimidation and tyranny. People of the Middle East are increasingly turning to freedom and democracy. We should be ensuring that everybody in this parliament—not just the government but the whole parliament—supports this campaign as best we can. I mentioned yesterday the speech of the British Foreign Secretary, Jack Straw, to the Fabian Society, applauding the movements towards freedom and democracy in the Middle East and making the point that you could not divorce that from what has happened in Iraq.

Even the US Democrat senator Ted Kennedy says that what has taken place in the Middle East is ‘enormously constructive’ and ‘a reflection the President has been involved’. That is an extraordinary concession coming from somebody like Senator Kennedy, who is an eternal critic of the Republican Party and has been a strong critic of President Bush.

In conclusion, let me remind the House again about the British MP, the left-wing member for North East Derbyshire, the redoubtable Harry Barnes. I am trying to check this, but I think my parents-in-law may actually live in his electorate, although they would not vote for him of course. They would certainly never vote Labour, but maybe they could be persuaded to next time because Harry Barnes is somebody with a bit of courage. He is somebody who has adopted the strong position of helping to set up the Labour Friends of Iraq. Let us remind ourselves of what he said:

quote.para: … we must face the facts if we are to provide solidarity to Iraqi democrats in their hour of utmost need. My plain message to those on the left who ... rubbish Iraqi democracy because they cannot stand the idea that ... Blair or ... Bush get some sort of credibility from them is to get real and do so quickly.

answer.para: In Britain, Labour Friends of Iraq, which costs £30 to join, are supporting the Iraqi Federation of Trade Unions. They are supporting the Iraqi labour movement, and that is what the Labor Party in Australia should do.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. I draw the Prime Minister’s attention to his remarks about interest rates:

quote.para: It is important that we preserve a sense of proportion.

question.para: Does the Prime Minister expect Australian families to keep a sense of proportion when they are paying $32 a month extra for a $200,000 mortgage, $48 a month extra for a $300,000 mortgage and $64 a month extra for a $400,000 mortgage? Did the Prime Minister play politics with family mortgage issues in order to get elected?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
talker.role: Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr HOWARD

talk.start.para: —The answer to the second question is no. As to my call to have a sense of proportion, I stand by that. I simply make the point that if the Leader of the Opposition wants an intelligent, engaged debate on this issue, he would recognise that, if you go back over the last 20 years, interest rates in this country at the present time, notwithstanding the recent increase, are at very low levels.
—What about your campaign?

—I know that the Leader of the Opposition finds this painful, and the member for Lilley interjects about campaigns. Yes, I did campaign very strongly on interest rates. I do not regret anything I said to the Australian people because everything I said about interest rates was true. I reminded the Australian people that when Labor was last in office, housing interest rates went to 17 per cent, small business rates to 20 per cent and bill rates for farmers went to 21 per cent.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order!

—Since we have been in government, interest rates have moved between six and eight per cent compared with 10 and 17 per cent for Labor. There is nothing falsified about that; there is nothing exaggerated about it. I stand by the statement I made to the Australian people that interest rates under the coalition will always be lower than interest rates under Labor.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon Sheikha Lubna Al Qasimi, Minister for Economy and Planning, and His Excellency Sultan Bin Saeed Al Mansouri, Minister for Communications for the United Arab Emirates. On behalf of the House I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

speech.para: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer outline to the House the benefits that tax reform has provided to consumers in business by providing for the abolition of inefficient state taxes? Are there signs further tax relief could soon be delivered?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr COSTELLO

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Goldstein for his question. As he would remember, and as members of this House would remember, when the government went to the Australian public to introduce a goods and services tax, it made it entirely clear that this was a replacement tax for other indirect taxes; that the Commonwealth would abolish the wholesale sales tax, which it did; and that the Commonwealth would expect the states to abolish their indirect taxes. This would start with bed taxes, financial institutions duty, reducing their gambling taxes and abolishing their bank account debits taxes.

answer.para: When the GST legislation was finally negotiated through the Senate, the base was not as broad as the government had proposed and there was some doubt as to whether the revenue would be great enough for the states to abolish those taxes. It was agreed that we would wait until 2005 and review the issue. I can report to the House that the actual receipts of GST are greater than we expected when we came to that agreement in 1999. Of the $35 billion in revenue going to the states this year, they will be getting a windfall of $1.9 billion over the guaranteed amount. That means there is now no excuse not to abolish those indirect state taxes which are to be replaced by the GST.

There will be a meeting of state treasurers with the Commonwealth on 23 March where this matter will be decided. I want to say to the House that there have been some welcome developments overnight. In particular, there have been welcome developments from the Queensland government. The Queensland Treasurer, Mr Mackenroth, is quoted in today’s Courier Mail as saying that he will be coming to the meeting on 23 March with an open mind. He said:

quote.para: We will go into the meeting … with an open mind … we have to have enough money to deliver services.

answer.para: But he accepts that the windfall will be available for the abolition of some of those state taxes. He said:

quote.para: We will see what we can deliver, but we won’t be bludgeoned by Canberra over it …

answer.para: There is no intention whatsoever to bludgeon states; there is an intention to keep to the agreement of 1999. Nothing could be more simple.

Let me make two points. The first point is that those states which abolish their inefficient indirect taxes and which now have the capacity to do something will be doing something for their own consumers and businesses. The second point is that, if states like Queensland are prepared to lead the way, it will be the state of Queensland that will steal the economic advantage from other states that follow. I would say to the states as they come to that meeting on 23 March that those states that lead the way and abolish their tax bases will be the states that will attract investment and whose people will have improved standards of living.

The government welcomes the statement that has been made by Mr Mackenroth overnight. I would have hoped that both sides of this House would have joined together in maintaining the Commonwealth’s position on the abolition of state indirect taxes and the ending of double taxation as a consequence. There has been an eerie silence from federal Labor. Why? Because the Leader of the Opposition is a patsy for the state premiers and he cannot stand up to them. That is the truth of the matter. He has been shown up by Terry Mackenroth, whose stand on this we welcome. We urge the other state treasurers and premiers to follow the lead that is coming out of Queensland.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister confirm that on ABC radio today he said: ‘The current weakness on our trade account will only be temporary’? Is the Prime Minister aware that Australia has recorded 39 monthly trade deficits in a row, that export growth under his government is under half that achieved by Labor and that, as a consequence, Australia is currently running its largest ever current account deficit, at 7.1 per cent of GDP? Is the Prime Minister also aware that the Treasury has already revised down by half, from eight per cent to four per cent, its export growth forecasts for this year? On what basis does the Prime Minister assert that the weakness on our trade account is only temporary? Where is his evidence?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
talker.role: Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr HOWARD

talk.start.para: —I did make a comment substantially to that effect. It is based on a belief—and there is evidence around of this—of an improvement later in the year of our export performance.
—My question is to the Minister for Trade. Would the minister advise the House of Australia’s strengthening trade and economic relationship with the United Arab Emirates?

talker.name: Vaile, Mark, MP
talker.role: Minister for Trade
talker.name: Mr VAILE

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Maranoa for his question and recognise that he chairs the Australia-UAE Parliamentary Friendship Group. This morning in the building I co-chaired the fourth Australia-UAE Joint Ministerial Commission with Minister Sheikha Lubna Al Qasimi and her colleagues from the UAE government, who are visiting Australia with a rather large business delegation at this time. This is the fourth joint ministerial commission that has been held. It is a very important mechanism for strengthening and enhancing an already significant economic relationship between Australia and the Emirates. The UAE is Australia’s second-largest export market in the Middle East. Two-way merchandise trade stood at about $2.2 billion in 2004. Importantly, two-way trade in services stands at $1.5 billion between Australia and the Emirates.

answer.para: As a result of the discussions that took place in the JMC this morning, this relationship is set to grow and expand even further, following agreement reached between my UAE ministerial colleagues and me to begin negotiations on a free trade agreement between Australia and the United Arab Emirates. It is a very important market in the Middle East, as I indicated. This will be Australia’s first free trade agreement negotiation with a country from the Middle East region—a significant step forward. Australian exporters can expect big gains and opportunities from a prospective free trade agreement with the Emirates.

The Emirates is a regional financial and transportation hub—the Singapore of the Middle East, if you like. It is a launch pad into the Gulf and Middle East markets and a very important trading partner of Australia’s, as I indicated. Currently, over 100 Australian companies have their regional headquarters in Dubai and over 6,000 Australians reside in the UAE. The Emirates has enormous oil and capital reserves and it is looking to diversify its investment portfolio as its economy is forecast to continue to grow at current rates. A free trade agreement with the Emirates was a key element of the government’s trade policy commitments at the last election. This demonstrates not only our government’s dedication to implementing our election commitments but also our dedication and approach to delivering ongoing market access improvements around the world for Australian exporters.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to his claim yesterday that the government solved tax disincentives in last year’s budget. Is the Treasurer aware that a senior Treasury official has admitted to a Senate estimates committee that budget measures worsened disincentives for some low-income families? Was this confirmed by the Melbourne Institute’s analysis of the package, which found these poorer incentives would have resulted in 22,000 individuals leaving the labour market? In the light of this evidence, why does the Treasurer continue to assert that last year’s budget package fixed the tax trap for low-income families? Why do so many on his back bench disagree with him?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr COSTELLO

talk.start.para: —I would like to refer to the case that has been raised by the Melbourne Institute, which has been referred to by the honourable member for Lilley. The case is a single earner on a minimum wage with one child under five. On a weekly income of $467.30 such a person would pay $66.57 in tax. They would receive $58.59 in parenting payment, $78.76 in FTBA and $57.49 in FTBB for a total of $194.83. They would receive a low-income rebate of $2.43.

answer.para: They have a private income of $467.30, parenting payments and FTB of $194.83 and in taxation a net figure of $64.13. Out of the weekly wage of $467.30 they have a disposable income of $598.10—that is, in net terms not only do they not pay tax but they receive more in tax benefits than they actually pay in tax. Let me turn it around another way. After their tax benefits are taken into account, on an annual basis their income jumps from $24,299 to $31,096—that is, instead of paying tax, that family actually receives in tax benefits in net terms $6,796. The person on the minimum wage pays no tax and, after they receive their tax benefits, receives in net terms an additional $6,796. They receive $6,796.

What did the budget this year do for that family? Let me tell you. The budget this year made that family $23 a week better off. How did the budget make that family $23 a week better off? It made it $23 a week better off because it increased family tax benefit A by $600 per annum, it increased the free area for the family tax benefit by $420 and it increased the amount for the family tax benefit by $150 from 1 January, but that will be $300 in a full year. With the changes to the tapers, the free areas and the amounts, that family through this year’s budget was made $23 a week better off. It was already in a net refund position and it was made $23 a week better off.

If the member for Lilley were really worried about this family, Mr Speaker, you would think that his policy at the last election would have made that family better off, wouldn’t you? Because otherwise it would just be hot air. I do not think he would be running around mouthing concern for this family if his actual policy did not make them better off. But I have to let the House into a secret—he had a policy for this family at the last election. Do you know what it was? It was to strip them of $600 of family tax benefit part A. Is that right? It would not be the case, would it, that the member for Lilley would run around professing concern for a family who he wanted to actually strip of benefits? That would not be the case! A white-bread politician would not be that cynical—oh, no!

In the last budget we increased by $600 family tax benefit A, we increased the free area for family tax benefit B, we reduced the taper for family tax benefit B and we increased the amount. That family was made $23 a week better off and is in a net refund position—a position that the member for Lilley wanted to oppose.

talk.start.para: —My question is also addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer outline to the House what research the Productivity Commission will be undertaking into the long-term education and supply of health professionals, including doctors and nurses?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr COSTELLO

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question and acknowledge the considerable expertise that he brings to health issues in this House. Today I am announcing a Productivity Commission report to study the long-term education and supply of health professionals in Australia with a view to taking away any regulatory or competitive blocks preventing the training of sufficient doctors, nurses and specialists to meet Australia’s needs in the future.

answer.para: In its landmark report released back in 2002, the Intergenerational report, the Commonwealth showed that no area of expenditure will increase faster over the next 40 years than health. Health is expected to grow from 4.7 per cent of GDP today to 9.9 per cent of GDP in 2040. The consequences of that are that, if we are to maintain the standards that we have today, if we are to respond to technological developments and if we are to cope with the ageing of the population, expenditures will double in proportion to GDP—meaning that, if you want to keep Australia on the same tax base, other areas of expenditure commensurately will have to recede. That is the implication of the ageing of the population.

This government has already put in place measures to boost the supply of doctors and nurses. But in response to a COAG request and state government requests the government will commission the Productivity Commission to look at those restrictions on supply, including restrictions on the supply of specialists. There is a concern that in relation to specialist training not as many specialists are being trained. In order to meet that looming demographic change and technological change, we will have to boost the supply of health services. The Productivity Commission report which I am announcing today will go a long way down that track.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that last Friday General Peter Cosgrove, Chief of the Defence Force, explained how the national squeeze on skills is now hurting Defence recruitment, by saying:

quote.para: We’re struggling with ... competition. I think we share Australia’s issue with people going into trades.

question.para: Prime Minister, don’t General Cosgrove’s comments demonstrate that after nine years the government’s failure on skills has not only stunted economic capacity growth but is undermining our military capacity?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
talker.role: Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr HOWARD

talk.start.para: —The answer to the first part of the question is yes. The answer to the second part of the question is no. I do not believe it is a justified construction of the remarks made by General Cosgrove to reach the conclusion that the Leader of the Opposition did in the concluding part of his question. It is true, as the government clearly laid out in the election campaign, that this country is suffering a skills shortage. It is largely a result of our economy having performed so strongly. That is the reason. There is no secret.

answer.para: What the Leader of the Opposition should be reminded of is that every time he complains about this expenditure of $66 billion he is complaining about the more than $1 billion that the government invested in skills upgrading. He is complaining about the $14 billion of tax cuts. He is complaining about the $23 billion of family tax benefits. He is complaining about the additional expenditure on roads infrastructure. The Leader of the Opposition has a problem: he excitedly runs after the latest headline in a newspaper without understanding that, unless you have a consistency of policy, unless you recall your previous stances, you can get yourself into a great deal of difficulty.

This country does have a skills shortage and this government has never sought to deny that. It is a function of a very strongly performing economy, and this government is putting in place a large number of measures to address the skills shortage.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I hear calls from the opposition about ‘nine years’. Let me go back nine years; let me go back a bit further than nine years. Do you know how many apprentices there were in December 1995? Were there 200,000? No, there were 143,700. How many were there in September 2004? There were 393,800. In other words, we are very proud of the commitment that we have made to apprentices throughout the nine years that this government has been in office. We are very proud of the commitment we have had to training. But does more remain to be done? Yes. That is why, in the fullness of time, the commitments we made in the last election campaign will come into effect.

answer.para: There has been enormous interest expressed in the construction and development of the 24 Australian technical colleges around Australia. I notice that, in the last election campaign, the former Leader of the Opposition opposed the Australian technical colleges. I am pleased to note that I think the current Leader of the Opposition has reversed that policy. I am not absolutely certain—maybe he could clarify that, maybe he could make it clear that he is definitely going to support it. There is no doubt that this country does need to adopt new measures to address the skills shortage, and that is exactly what the government is doing.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education. Would the minister advise the House how school based new apprenticeships are giving young people greater opportunities for training and employment?

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr HARDGRAVE

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Braddon for his question. He and so many people on this side of the House are very enthusiastic about giving support to the various choices young people seek. In fact, we saw a 52 per cent increase in the number of school based new apprenticeships in the 12 months to September last year. In fact, there are now over 12½ thousand school based new apprentices. But, sadly, over half of those are in one state alone. It is sad, because a school based new apprentice is somebody more likely to actually complete their training, because of the environment they start that training in. These apprenticeships include the hospitality, retail, agriculture, forestry, property, building services, building and construction and manufacturing sectors. Since 2000 the numbers have surged from just 2,370 a year to this magnificent figure of 12½ thousand plus. This gives young people the opportunity to gain nationally recognised trade qualifications and work experience while they are still at school.

answer.para: The Australian government are committed to this process. Over the next three years, out of that $66 billion the Labor Party does not like us spending, we are providing an extra $17.9 million, which will create an additional 7,000 school based new apprenticeship places through group training organisations. This will of course address so many of the skills demands in industries. It will increase career and training pathways available to school students.

The concern that we have on this side can actually be addressed by those on the other side: their political masters—the union movement and, indeed, the state governments, whom the Leader of the Opposition owes his career to—can in fact make a difference tomorrow. In the state of New South Wales there are no school based—that is, part-time—new apprentices in the trades with skill shortages. None, zero. In the biggest state of Australia, the answer is zero. We need to see a change in that. In Western Australia, in the building and construction trades, I am advised there are virtually no school based new apprentices. It is because of state based industrial awards that these starts are being prevented for young people.

The Australian technical college initiative—$289 million over the next three years—will provide more opportunities for school based new apprentices in years 11 and 12. We have made progress as a government, and we are determined to keep that progress coming.

talk.start.para: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon His Excellency Mr Alaedin Borujerdi, Chairman of the National Security and Foreign Policy Commission of the Islamic Republic of Iran. On behalf of the House, I extend him a very warm welcome.

speech.para: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that Maxi-TRANS, a manufacturing company in my electorate, has put on hold indefinitely eight apprenticeships for Australians in favour of importing boilermakers and welders from China? Prime Minister, isn’t it a fact that the Howard government’s belated response to the skills crisis is an imported skills quick fix instead of training Australians first?

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr HARDGRAVE

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to be able to answer this question, because it has been 100 days since the Labor Party have asked me one question on skills training—which repeats the mistake of the 40th Parliament, when they did not ask any. With regard to the specifics of the member for Ballarat’s question, let me advise that I have asked my department to make some direct inquiries into the MaxiTRANS new apprenticeship situation. We have been advised that the new apprentices in fact were being recruited through a local group training organisation. I have asked that group training organisation and the New Apprenticeships centres in the Ballarat region to work together to place with other host employers any new apprentices who were selected for MaxiTRANS and did not commence.

answer.para: But let us also deal with the sentiment that underscores this: a failure of the member for Ballarat—and, it seems, numbers of others opposite—to understand that the skilled migration program actually delivers a net benefit to the local community—

talk.start.para: Ms King interjecting—
—The member for Ballarat!

—and that it actually creates an opportunity for even more people to gain the apprenticeships that they might like to seek. Of course, over the years it has been developed to the point where as many as six or seven additional jobs can in fact be created—
Ms King interjecting—
—The member for Ballarat is warned!

—and opportunities given to more people as a result of employers in the local area working through the skilled migration program to bring people in directly to meet their company’s needs. These people do not come here simply because they want to. Very simply, it is a process by which the employers have to advertise the vacancy nationally. If they satisfy the process in not being able to find an Australian-sourced person for that vacancy, they need agreement—including from the local state government, in particular—to be able to import that person.

answer.para: Just for the record, the member for Ballarat might be interested to know that there are approximately 3,000 apprentices in training in her electorate, which is a 292 per cent increase since 1996. So I would invite the member for Ballarat to celebrate the fact that a local business is investing in itself and the local region and creating more job opportunities for more young people around Ballarat.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister inform the House of government measures to encourage mature age employment?

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Casey for his question and acknowledge the considerable interest which he takes in promoting opportunities for mature age workers in his electorate of Casey. In last year’s budget the government allocated $12.1 million to help mature age work seekers to continue to work and, indeed, made a further substantial commitment in the election platform last year. So the government is making a substantial commitment and providing substantial assistance to employers to assist mature age workers, but can I say that we also need to encourage employers to do more themselves. If one looks at the participation rate for people in Australia aged between 55 and 64, it stands at 53.4 per cent. This compares with the rates, for example, for the United Kingdom, which is at 57.5 per cent; the United States of America, which is at 62.4 per cent; and our nearest neighbour, New Zealand, which is at 66.8 per cent.

answer.para: Yesterday the government made announcements of awards to four companies under its Mature Age Workers Employer Champion awards. These are companies which have put in place policies not only to retain mature age workers but indeed to recruit older workers. I would like to commend those companies—the Westpac Banking Corporation, Socobell OEM of Spotswood in Melbourne, Aurora Energy in Tasmania and Magnet Mart here in Canberra—for their policies in developing age-friendly workplaces. One of the consequences of the ageing population in Australia will be a contraction in the coming years in the net growth of the Australian work force. Therefore, one of the measures which we are seeking to encourage employers and businesses throughout Australia to adopt is to retain and indeed to regain older workers.

These proposals and this program stand in marked contrast to the program that the Leader of the Opposition employed when he was the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, back in the previous government, and the member for Lilley was the chairman of the special caucus committee on long-term unemployment. Indeed, in May 1993, the then Labor government, with the Leader of the Opposition as the minister for employment, proposed the idea of paying old age pensions to unemployed people from the age of 55 and no longer counting them as part of the work force. So, instead of doing something to assist mature age workers, the policy of the Leader of the Opposition when he was last responsible for employment was simply to give up and to pension off these people from the work force. No wonder he told his biographer subsequently: ‘I lost a lot of ambition and I stopped straining. I thought there was less capacity to achieve in that portfolio than in just about anything that I had.’ Instead of rising to the challenge to assist mature age workers, the Leader of the Opposition squibbed it. We will not do that.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education. Is the minister aware that, according to the Skills at work report released last week, a staggering 40 per cent of people who start a new apprenticeship do not complete their training? Minister, doesn’t this show that the Howard government’s New Apprenticeships scheme is not meeting the needs of trainees and apprentices and does not give them proper training?

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr HARDGRAVE

talk.start.para: —Finally, a question from the opposition directly to me. It has taken 100 days for them to actually raise apprenticeships directly with me. But, as I said the other day, there are lots of galahs in the pet shop, not just parrots. The Skills at work report showed that the number of completions of new apprenticeships has in fact increased by 280 per cent since 1996. Over the 12 months to June 2003, the period of the report, around 120,500 new apprenticeships were completed. We need to see the Australian Labor Party actually get behind the efforts of the government to keep encouraging the choices that young people make and to celebrate the process of choice that is at work in the marketplace today. The number of people starting apprenticeships across the board is up; the number of people starting apprenticeships in traditional trades is up; the completions are up; the funding is up. If only the Labor Party would actually have the good grace and decency to encourage young people to feel good about their choices, just as we are doing on this side of the chamber.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Would the minister inform the House of the government’s plans for the introduction of voluntary student unionism? Are there any alternative proposals?

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Indi for her question. She in particular and many members on this side have committed much of their adult lives to fighting for the fundamental principle that every Australian should be free to join a union, a guild or an association and be represented by that union if they so choose but that equally every Australian, whether they be in a workplace or a university campus, should be free to not join a union. This government will very shortly introduce legislation to give effect to the long-held Liberal principle that, when Australian university students—there are now 750,000 of them—arrive on campus each year, they should have the choice to join a union, a guild or association or equally they should be free not to join that union.

answer.para: I say to the members opposite, to the people who lecture us constantly from what they consider to be a social justice viewpoint: why should a single parent, a mother of two, who goes back to university to study nursing subsidise the abseiling club? Why should she subsidise buses to Woomera or the purchase of axes to break down the vice-chancellor’s offices? Why is it that students who want to enrol in a diploma of language at Sydney University and who then have to do a course at ANU in India are sent a bill for ANU union fees, when all they want to do is to get an education at Sydney University? Why is it that a student in the 21st century goes to Sydney University to pay $2 for a sausage roll when they can buy one for $1.70 off campus and be served by a person who actually smiles at them?
Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The House will come to order. The member for Oxley!

—I put this to the Australian Labor Party, which are opposed to Australian students having a choice to join a union: not a single word was said by the Labor Party when the sons and daughters of struggling families faced a 300 per cent increase in TAFE fees in New South Wales—up-front charges from the New South Wales government—yet, here they are, railing against Australian students having the choice to join a union or not. This government will not be deterred from its course of action. This will be implemented in 2005.
—Order! The Member for New England has the call.
Mr Ripoll interjecting—
—The member for Oxley is warned.

—My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister. Deputy Prime Minister, in evidence to the Senate inquiry into regional partnerships, Greg Maguire admitted under oath that, several days after meeting with the Deputy Prime Minister for 90 minutes, he said to me:

quote.para: You—
should roll over and talk to the Liberal or National parties.
You could write your own deal.
You could probably do whatever you wanted, even an overseas posting.
There would be jobs for the boys.
Go and talk to John Anderson.

question.para: Did you, Deputy Prime Minister, discuss my political future with Greg Maguire on 13 May 2004?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr ANDERSON

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question. As I recall, and as the man in question has indicated, he indicated to me that he felt that you had become an ineffective member for that seat. He indicated, as indeed many members of the Tamworth business community have indicated to me, that they would like to see a change in representation. He himself said all of that in the Senate hearing the other day. So, in that sense, have members of the Tamworth business community talked to me about their representation? Yes. Did I say to him in some form or another that I had some offer to make to you? Very specifically, as I have said endlessly in this place, no I did not.

—My question is to the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. Would the minister advise the House of reaction to yesterday’s announcement on progress towards the introduction of choice in superannuation?

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr BROUGH

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I can inform the House that yesterday’s announcement of the new regulations, form and legislation going forward on the government’s choice of superannuation fund from 1 July was very well received. In fact, Mr Richard Gilbert, the Chief Executive Officer of the Investment and Financial Services Association, said:

quote.para: This is a good result for investors and consumers.

answer.para: Whilst it is important that industry and business are engaged in and supportive of choice, the most important people in this equation are the consumers. I was particularly pleased to read an article in the Australian newspaper today which asked a typical young 23-year-old worker in the Sydney suburb of Bronte, Mr David Birtwell, about choice. He said that he was ‘eager to control where his superannuation money was placed so he could ensure he paid minimum fees for maximum returns’. It is a pretty simple concept and one that we on this side of that House fully support. Mr Birtwell went on to say:

quote.para: I think it is definitely beneficial to have a choice. ... if I can choose, I will definitely take much more of an interest in it.

answer.para: It is very important that Australians take a very keen interest in their superannuation and choice will encourage them to do just that. I asked myself why those who sit opposite and their Labor state colleagues are opposed to choice, opposed to giving a fundamental right to average consumers to make what is probably the second largest financial decision of their lives beyond buying their own homes—that is, where they are going to place their superannuation, what sorts of fees they are going to be charged and what sorts of returns they expect to receive.

The Labor Party are incapable of making these sorts of decisions on behalf of the public. They have now said that they do not believe Australian consumers should have a right to choose where their super funds go. Tom Barton, the Queensland Minister for Employment, Training and Industrial Relations and a former union heavyweight in Queensland, proudly stated, when he reintroduced into the state parliament the removal of the little bit of choice that was there for state workers, that he had consulted with employers and unions. There was no suggestion that he had consulted with the people most affected, the workers themselves, the people whose money it is that is in choice. I encourage the Labor Party to think again, repudiate their current policy position and support choice.

subdebateinfo.title: Federal Election: Member for New England

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister and follows the one that was asked of him by the honourable member for New England. Did the Deputy Prime Minister not say to the House on 18 November last year that the reason Ms Wendy Armstrong left the room during the 13 May meeting held with Mr Greg Maguire was so Mr Maguire could show the Deputy Prime Minister his ‘quite extraordinary collection of motorcycles’. Why didn’t the Deputy Prime Minister tell the House then what he has told the House now: that he and Mr Maguire in fact discussed the political future of the member for New England?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr ANDERSON

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question and I say the innuendo and the presumption that goes with that are disgusting and a disgrace. If he has an allegation to make he might first begin by declaring straight up and down whether he has confidence in the Australian Federal Police and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions who found that there was no case. The direct answer to his question is that there is no conflict whatsoever in terms of the substantive purpose for which I was requested to meet with Mr Maguire to talk about the proposed equine centre. We had a conversation about the matter that was at hand. No inducements were offered. Your implication somehow now that you want to make accusations, that you want to get into the swim of this, first demands that you make clear what your allegation is and whether or not in some way you are casting doubts on the findings of the Australian Federal Police. Later in the meeting—

answer.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Yes, we went and looked at motorcycles. There is no conflict whatsoever between what I said then and what happened on the night—none.
—Before calling the next member, I remind the Deputy Prime Minister to address his remarks through the chair.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Small Business and Tourism. Would the minister outline to the House the contribution small business makes to the economy. What are the disincentives to small business growing and employing more Australians?

talker.name: Bailey, Fran, MP
talker.role: Minister for Small Business and Tourism
talker.name: FRAN BAILEY

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for McMillan for his question and acknowledge that he has been a very successful small businessman in regional Victoria and is passionate about small business. We have 1.1 million small businesses in this country employing 3.3 million Australians. They play a very central role in the economy because they generate around 30 per cent of the economic production. The government values and recognises this contribution by small business and provides a range of assistance so that small business can grow. Programs like the 25 per cent entrepreneurs’ tax discount will provide $1.1 billion of tax cuts to 300,000 small businesses. I am asked: are there disincentives for small business to grow and employ more people? I can tell the House that one of that biggest disincentives for small business is the hike in land tax that state Labor governments are applying to small business right around the country. The two states who are the worst offenders are New South Wales and Victoria. Victoria has increased its grab for land tax.

answer.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I think this is an important issue and I should be heard.
—Order! The minister will continue.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. As I was saying, Victoria has increased its grab for land tax by 123 per cent. The New South Wales grab for land tax this year is going to be $1.4 billion. On the ground, that means that small businesses like Dennison’s Dry Cleaning in Camberwell in Victoria have had their land tax increased over the past five years from $947 to $20,500. It also means, on the ground, that the small business people running Arthur’s Hotel in Arthur’s Seat have had their land tax increased from $1,330 to $46,130. If the Leader of the Opposition had the slightest interest in small business, he would actually speak to his Labor counterparts in each of the states and convince them to reduce this burden on small business and give small business a fair go.

—My question is again to the Deputy Prime Minister. I ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether he recollects this, which was his answer in its entirety to the question that I referred to from my predecessor:

quote.para: No, I did not ask my adviser to leave the room because there was a sensitive matter to be discussed. The purpose of the meeting, which was to discuss the equine centre, was concluded and Mr Maguire wanted to show me over his quite extraordinary collection of motorcycles, which is what he did, in that magnificent museum. To those of you who travel through Tamworth, I recommend that you stop and have a look at it.

question.para: Why did you not tell the House then that you had in fact discussed with Mr Maguire the detail of your conversations—

talk.start.para: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The member for Mackellar has a point of order.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: standing order 100(d)(iv) says that imputations may not be included in questions. Page 527 of the House of Representatives Practice says that the previous Speaker did not intervene where it was a matter of philosophy or viewpoint but did intervene where the attribution of personal motive was such that it could not be ignored. That is precisely what is happening here with the Leader of the Opposition and his questions are quite out of order. If he wishes to continue, it should be by way of substantive motion. He is out of order.

—The member will resume her seat. I would say to the Leader of the Opposition that, while this is certainly referring to a previous answer, he should not imply motives to the Deputy Prime Minister; he should ask a straight question.

—I agree with you completely, Mr Speaker. That is exactly what I should do and that is what I am attempting to do. I ask the Deputy Prime Minister, following that quote: why did you not refer in your answer to that question to the fact that you had discussed with Mr Maguire the situation of the member for New England and what was the character of your discussions?
Mr Wilkie interjecting—
—The member for Swan is warned.
—The House will come to order!

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr ANDERSON

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The simple point to be made in all this, as I made very plain last year and as I have reiterated every time I have been asked since, and I do so again today—and as is completely corroborated by Mr Maguire’s testimony to the Senate committee last week—is that at no stage was any corrupt or inappropriate offer made or asked to be conveyed. In no way was there anything that is out of order in terms of the Electoral Act or in terms of decent behaviour. Are we at the point where a discussion, which inasmuch as it had to do with politics had to do with our candidate in that seat, should be fully reported in this House?
Mr Swan interjecting—
—The member for Lilley is warned.
—The main issue so far as the public interest is concerned is that no inducement was offered. The businessman at the centre of this confirmed that last week.
Mr Kelvin Thomson interjecting—
—The member for Wills is warned.

—And there is no conflict whatsoever. There is not the slightest conflict or inconsistency between what I said last year and what I maintain and will continue to maintain until I depart this earth: no inappropriate offer was made.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Ageing. Would the minister advise the House of the government’s initiatives to increase investment and quality care in aged care services?

talker.name: Bishop, Julie, MP
talker.role: Minister for Ageing
talker.name: Ms JULIE BISHOP

talk.start.para: —I acknowledge the member for Forde’s interest in aged care and thank her for arranging an aged care forum when I visited her electorate. The Australian government is committed to ensuring that older Australians receive not only high-quality care and choice in care but also high-quality accommodation if they need residential care. That is why the government introduced a 10-year certification program to ensure that by 2008 aged care homes meet community expectations in terms of building standards and the privacy and amenity in those homes. I am pleased to report to the House that already around 90 per cent of homes meet that 2008 certification standard.

answer.para: The sector is showing great confidence in the government’s policies and continuing reform agenda in aged care. The most recent survey of aged care homes indicates that some $2 billion in private investment has been made either for work carried out or for work in progress to 30 June last year. Some 25 per cent or one in four homes report that they are planning new work in their homes. The Australian government committed almost a billion dollars over four years in the last budget in capital payments to aged care homes.

In addition, recently I was able to announce the outcome of the 2004 allocation—a $40 million capital fund for rural and regional homes. I know, for example, that the member for Lingiari will be pleased that a home in Alice Springs in his electorate received $2½ million by way of a capital payment. Indeed, the member for Kennedy, whom I see here today, would also be pleased that the Fred Leftwich Rest Home received a $2½ million capital payment. I visited the Fred Leftwich hostel last year and I was very impressed with the work that they are doing in Mareeba for Aboriginal and Tourist Strait Islanders needing care. My colleague the member for Eden-Monaro has already indicated to me how pleased the people are at the Sir William Hudson Memorial Centre in his electorate, which is providing high care for people in rural areas. They have received a targeted grant of $1 million. So the combination of Australian government investment and private sector investment from the aged care sector, together with our ongoing reform program, is securing the future for aged care in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talker.name: Mr COSTELLO,MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr COSTELLO

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I table the calculation that I referred to in question time, which shows that somebody on a minimum wage of $24,299.60 receives in family tax benefits more than they pay in income tax and is in a net receipt position from the government of $130.70 per week—$6,796 per annum.

motionnospeech.name: Mr McGAURAN
motionnospeech.inline: —Documents are presented as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the documents will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and I move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the following documents:

item.para: Australian Technology Group Limited—Financial statements for 2004.
Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs—Access and equity report for 2004.
Finance—Mid-year economic and fiscal outlook—2004-05.
Treaties—Bilateral—Text, together with national interest analysis and annexures—
Singapore–Australia Free Trade Agreement Amendments.

motionnospeech.para: Debate (on motion by Ms Gillard) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honorable member for Jagajaga proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The damaging impact of the government’s skills crisis on Australian families, businesses and the economy

subdebate.1.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I want to start with a story about a fantastic Far Side cartoon that reminds me of the absolute farce that we saw in question time today. It had two cowboys standing over the body of a third cowboy. One cowboy has a smoking gun and he is staring at the body on the ground saying, ‘Okay, stranger; what’s the circumference of the earth?’ or ‘Who wrote the Odyssey and the Iliad?’ or ‘What is the average rainfall of the Amazon Basin?’ The other cowboy has his hands to his face and he is saying, ‘Bart, you fool; you can’t shoot first and ask questions later.’ It is, I have to say, Far Side at its best and, of course, aptly describes the absurdity of what the Prime Minister is trying to pull off. Just substitute the Prime Minister and the Treasurer for these two standing cowboys and Australia’s training system for the cowboy who is laid out on the floor—the one who has been shot—and imagine the questions the Prime Minister is shouting over the training system’s mortally wounded carcass.

speech.para: We do, of course, have insightful gems from the Prime Minister when he asks: why doesn’t Australia have enough skilled workers? Of course, you get the general idea. We have a Prime Minister, a Treasurer and education ministers who have spent nine years shooting the heck out of Australia’s training system and then asking questions about why all of a sudden we have this skills crisis in Australia. This government has had nine years to fix this problem—nine years in which it has created a skills crisis in Australia that is hurting business and hurting families and, most significantly now, is the reason behind the latest interest rate rise that is hurting our economy.

The government has been in office for nine years. We have had a severe shortage of skilled workers, and this Prime Minister has nobody to blame but himself, yet during this time the government has actually turned away 270,000 people from TAFE—that is, just since 1998. We also know that the government has lagged behind the spending of the states when it comes to vocational education and training. We know that, when this government first came in, it actually cut funding to vocational education and training in 1998 and 1999, and it took until 2002 for federal funding to reach 1997 levels again. Is it any wonder that this country is facing the crisis that it is?

We heard the member for Ballarat today ask a question about an important company in her electorate which has put on hold indefinitely eight apprenticeships for Australians in favour of having to import boilermakers and welders from China. This means that we now have a situation in Ballarat where young Australians are not getting the training that they need, and this government decides that it will go for the quick fix of bringing in skilled workers from overseas, all because it has spent the last nine years being complacent about skilled training.

We have already seen a massive increase in the level of skilled migration during this government’s time in office—and this is something that really has not been talked about much—but the government’s response to the skills crisis now that they have finally woken up to it is only one thing, and that is to bring in more skilled migrants from overseas. But that is only a short-term political fix. It is certainly not a substitute for a long-term program of training Australians first. When the Leader of the Opposition raised a question about this in question time, we discovered that this government is actually threatening Australia’s national security because of the skills crisis as well.

The fig leaf that the government have been trying to use for the last little while about this skills crisis had to be removed when the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education was forced to reveal the Skills at work document just last week. That revealed—and this is the point that everybody on the government side has finally woken up to—that most of the growth in new apprenticeships is in areas where there is no skills shortage. Most of the growth is going to those areas where we are not short of skilled labour. The share of traditional trades, as part of the new apprenticeships, has actually halved since 1996. Between 2000 and 2003, we saw the number of trades apprentices decline, while sales and service apprenticeships rose by about 25,000 people. That is what has been happening under this government.

The report that the minister was forced to release also shows that a staggering 40 per cent of people who start a new apprenticeship do not even complete their training. They go into one of these traineeships but they never complete their training. That is yet another reason why we have such a serious shortage. Of the people who do complete their training, what do they say about the quality of the training they get? Half of them say that their skills do not improve. They go into these traineeships and, in response to a government questionnaire, half of them say their skills do not improve. Six per cent actually say they have less skills than when they started—damning evidence from the government’s own report that their New Apprenticeships scheme is certainly not meeting the needs of trainees or apprentices. It is not giving them the skills they need, let alone meeting the needs of the economy.

So what is the story from the government and their New Apprenticeships scheme? We have far too few people starting apprenticeships in the traditional trades, we have people not completing their training and we have people saying that the training they get is not actually adding to their skills. The whole New Apprenticeships scheme is really just an exercise in smoke and mirrors. The government have, of course, been crowing for years about the increased number of new apprenticeships. They went about that by introducing a fiddle back in 1998 to include traineeships in a range of service industries and to count them as apprenticeships. Of course, nobody who knows anything about real apprenticeships would count these traineeships as what people would normally understand an apprenticeship to be.
Back in 2002 the Australian Financial Review really got it right when they said in one of their analyses:

quote.para: The mantra of “record numbers”—

speech.para: and the minister should listen to this—

quote.para: of apprentices and trainees chanted by successive Federal Government ministers bears some similarity to Soviet propaganda about record production under the command economy.

speech.para: The paper went on to say:

quote.para: Some experts say the system is functioning in part as a source of cheap labour, and this has driven the record-breaking numbers of people in training.

speech.para: So that is what has been driving the record number in training. It is not actually people going into proper traditional trades who would be able to address the skills shortage. The Financial Review were obviously very concerned about this back in 2002, as they went on the next day to say:

quote.para: Experts reckon wage subsidies, rather than the urge to train more people, have inflated the numbers.

speech.para: That is what has really been going on. The government have been providing wage subsidies to some companies, calling them traineeships and then trying to count them as new apprenticeships. That is what has inflated the numbers. As the Financial Review said:

quote.para: It looks suspiciously like some churning is occurring, where employers take on workers as trainees and use the generous incentives and low training wages with little commitment to actual training.

speech.para: The nub of the problem with the system that the minister is now responsible for is:

quote.para: ... the training system may only be serving as a low-wage vehicle to get people into jobs.

speech.para: That is not an apprenticeship. That was two years ago, but the government have been clinging to this fig leaf on record numbers ever since. At last that fig leaf has been removed.

An excellent caller to an ABC radio program in Melbourne the other day really belled the cat on this issue. He talked about his wife, who had been made an apprentice at the age of 50. This story really sums up the problem with the minister’s scheme. At the age of 50, she was made an apprentice in process work, a job she had done for the last 24 years. Describing the Howard government’s New Apprenticeship scheme as ‘the apprentice scheme you have when you don’t really have one,’ the caller said his wife would be retiring in two to three years, just as she finishes her apprenticeship—which is actually, of course, not an apprenticeship. She is just a person who has had some wage subsidy money paid to her employer. She did not get any additional training. As her husband said, it is all about the apprenticeship scheme you have when you do not really have one.

It happens at the other end of the age spectrum as well. Young people go into training for companies, but the companies do not actually provide any training. All they are doing is taking the wage subsidy from the Howard government. All the Howard government are trying to do is pump up the numbers and make it look like they are doing something. They are trying to make it seem as if they have really been addressing this apprenticeship problem, but, most significantly, they are creating what we now have: a very, very serious skills crisis in this country. The Howard government have been misdirecting taxpayers’ dollars where no training is being provided and, in many other cases, putting the training into areas where there is no economic need. As a direct result of the government’s failure on training, we now have interest rate rises. As Tim Colebatch pointed out in the Age at the weekend:

quote.para: The main reason home mortgage repayments rose this week was that the Australian industry is short of skilled workers.

speech.para: That is something that this minister has to take full responsibility for when he goes around and has to front up to all of the people who are paying more for their mortgages: it is all because of this government’s failure on the skills shortage.

What about the cost of renovating? It is not only that mortgage rates have increased; we know that the cost of renovating has increased. If anyone who is listening has had to employ a plumber, an electrician or a carpenter, they would know how expensive it is. Overall, the cost of renovating increased by 8.3 per cent in the December quarter alone.

We know that in the traditional trades we have business crying out for more skilled labour, whether it is metal fitters, toolmakers, mechanics, electricians, carpenters or bricklayers. These are the people who are in desperately short supply. Where do we see this government increasing training? It is increasing training for clerical workers and sales assistants. That is this government’s priority, not the areas where business is crying out for more skilled labour.

Most shamefully, skills as a driver of productivity have dropped by 75 per cent over the last 10 years. There has been a 75 per cent drop in skills as a driver of productivity—all because this government has not made sure that investment is going in where skills are really needed.

We have the Reserve Bank, the OECD and now every Australian mortgage holder saying to the Howard government, ‘It’s your responsibility to make sure that we’ve got the skilled workers that we need so that we don’t see our interest rates continue to go through the roof.’ What have we had from this government? During the election campaign, we had a proposal to introduce these new technical colleges. These colleges will not produce one additional skilled tradesperson until 2010. That is five years away. We have a skills crisis right now—all because this government did not do something five years ago. Now they want to introduce these new technical colleges. In 2010—just get the dimension of what they are doing—there will be 3,600 people coming out of these technical colleges when the Australian Industry Group says that we need 100,000 extra skilled workers in the next five years.

What an initiative from this minister! We have a government that has certainly taken its eye off the ball. It has had plenty of early warnings. It was warned way back in 1999 and in the year 2000 by the Australian Industry Group and by Access Economics. All of these groups have been warning the Prime Minister. Yet on Sunday we had the Prime Minister saying that he identified this skills shortage months ago. Months ago! He identified it months ago. He has his eye on the ball. He has his eye right on the ball. He identified this problem months ago. Years ago, this was a problem. Years ago it was a problem because this government tried to fiddle the figures and did not deliver the skilled workers. (Time expired)

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr HARDGRAVE

talk.start.para: —The end of the speech of the member for Jagajaga could not come soon enough for her. It was a very strained contribution that the member for Jagajaga made today, under awful duress, talking about a subject that she had no real interest in until the last few weeks. During the entire 40th Parliament did she raise this subject matter? Did she raise any questions about increases in apprenticeships or increases in funding for training? No. Back on 7 December and again today she has finally raised some questions about it.

speech.para: The Australian Labor Party are exposed awfully on this entire policy initiative. By their utterances in this place and in other fora around the country, they have proved time and time again why the people of Australia so resoundingly endorsed the government at the last election. The Australian Labor Party are a blunt object when it comes to these sorts of things. Today they have come forward to put the case that suits the Australian Education Union. In debates on matters of public importance, we find that generally the union contributors to Labor Party coffers order the agenda of the day. Today is the Education Union’s turn.

The education system in this country uses a supply driven approach to education and training. That suits the union agenda. This is about supplying people, educating and training them, and hoping that employers will take these people on. This government is very determined to actually create a sense of partnership like there has never been before with Australian industry, to create the industry driven approach that industry itself is demanding. The people who actually hire apprentices are saying to us, ‘We want that partnership.’

Unlike the member for Jagajaga, I have been to 19 regions around Australia in the discussion on the Australian technical college proposal. The member for Casey was in one of those regional discussions; he is going to contribute to this debate today, and I am glad of that. What regions all around this country are saying is, ‘We know what our industry base is; we know what our education and training assets are; we want to support young people in gaining access to trade skills; we want to get on with the job.’ The only thing that the member for Jagajaga has put into any of those regions has been a press release—and it has been the same press release all around the country. It is quite an extraordinary set of press releases I have got from the member for Jagajaga. The northern Tasmanian one changed, I think, when the policy position of the Labor Party on the Australian technical colleges changed a week ago.
At the end of the day, the Labor Party are lazy on this whole issue. They have failed to recognise that since the 1997-98 budget we have increased overall VET funding by 35.5 per cent.

talk.start.para: —Rubbish.

—That has been the increase. I hear ‘Rubbish’ from the people opposite. These are the facts. If you look at the increases since the 1995 budget, the total Australian government contribution to VET has increased by 57½ per cent—a 57½ per cent increase in real terms: these are not nominal terms; these are real terms. This includes a large increase in the measures of support for new apprenticeships—importantly, in what are now regarded as skill shortage needs. Our national skill shortage strategy, which has been in place over the last couple of years, is directly addressing so many of those particular issues, looking at the traditional trades.

speech.para: What has happened just this calendar year, without an agreement on national training with the states? The states walked out of that in 2003—walked out and denied 71,000 people the chance to start in TAFEs around this country. That is 71,000 people who, if they had been given a start, might have had some of their demands met. But the states, for political reasons—and I suspect it had something to do with the fact that it was leading into an election year—rewarded TAFE students with, in New South Wales, up to a 300 per cent increase in TAFE fees. Did we get questions from the member for Jagajaga when that was occurring—not this year, but last year? No, there was no mention about that. At the end of the day, there was a 57½ per cent increase—a $1.154 billion commitment this year to the states and territories to deal with their aspects of training.

And then look at the skill shortages in the traditional trades. There is a lot of talk about traditional trades suddenly coming from what was once the great political party of the workers. Labor have lost their way. They are completely lost in the wilderness. We have seen a substantial 38 per cent increase of new apprentices in the trades and trade related occupations, covering trades such as carpenters, plumbers and electricians, even though those occupations only make up 13 per cent of the entire work force. We are seeing young Australians and their now employers backing their ambitions to get on with the job, grow the particular industry that they happen to be a part of and give these kids a solid base for the future. And yet all we hear in this place is a lampooning of the sorts of choices that people make. There was the disgraceful contribution from the member for Jagajaga in her ‘Big Mac attack’ last week, an absolutely disgraceful derision of people who seek traineeships at Hungry Jacks and McDonald’s. For the job snobbery that came from those opposite last week they should hang their heads in shame but there is no word of apology from them.

Since September 1996, we have seen an 18 per cent growth in new apprenticeships in trade and trade related occupations. That is from 126,100 in 1996 to 148,400 in September last year. These are substantial growth figures. The member for Jagajaga gave us a further insight into her thinking on this whole thing and we have seen evidence of this also from the Leader of the Opposition. There seems to be some suggestion that somewhere along the line this government should not only enforce Labor’s plan of ‘no ticket no start’ but also do it before they even get a start. In other words, we should be directing people into trades. We should somehow or other say, ‘You have no choice and no freedom.’ Those opposite do not like freedom of choice. They do not like to trust individual people. They would prefer to see us say, ‘There is a shortage over there so go and have that job or else you get nothing.’ We respect the choices that people make. It is amazing to think that this party—the Liberal Party and the National Party—is the party of the real workers of Australia. We have supported the choices that young people make with such comments as those made by the Prime Minister a weekend ago. He said quite clearly that we should respect the choices that young people leaving school at the end of year 10 make because the opportunities they might like to seek for themselves are real and they are choices they make quite freely.

But let me tell the House why the Labor Party are so embarrassed about this. Apprenticeships are an exercise in building the nation and our work force. We are still paying an enormous price for the legacy of the Leader of the Opposition’s years as the education minister. In fact, it was the single most dramatic decline—

talk.start.para: —You had nine years to do something about this.

—The member for Jagajaga can keep stewing on this but she can wait—I have got an answer for that too. The single most dramatic decline in apprenticeships in training occurred between 1992 and 1994 while under the portfolio responsibilities of the member for Brand. This led to a lack of employers in the system today. Fewer people in training years ago means fewer people in the trades today. Those who took on the trade training are the people most likely to take apprentices today, and there were fewer entered into the system between 1992 and 1994. Let me tell you: they were not just marginal losses. There were 143,900 in 1992—the year of the recession we had to have, engineered by the former Deputy Prime Minister in the Keating government, the member for Brand. The recession we apparently had to have killed apprenticeships to the extent that in 1992 there were 143,900 in the system and 122,700 in 1993. But wait—there is more. In 1994 the figure was 107,100. Then there was some growth the following year, so when we came to office in 1995 we found there was 143,000. We have built that up to almost 400,000 now. The Labor Party of course understand that they are very culpable on this. The so-called workers’ party that let the working people and their children down so severely when they were last in office are now trying to pretend that they have no responsibility for those failure years.

speech.para: The failure of the member for Brand’s years as the education minister was not the only failure that we need to address. The then current skill needs were a problem, but the failure to provide a framework for employers to allow for future capacity was completely eroded because of that failure to invest in those days. This government is not only about addressing those problems but also about addressing the future needs of Australia. That is why there are so many policy initiatives that were promised during the last election campaign to enhance the position, which I have already put, about the substantial growth that has been earned off the efforts and choices made by young people and by the industries that are now employing them. Those sorts of choices have been endorsed by the fact that training money has backed those choices and given people an opportunity to learn a trade, to learn a skill, to seek employment, to stay employed, to keep the economy growing and to then employ the next lot of potential employers, hopefully always with apprenticeships in every particular case.

At the end of the day, the single most damaging contribution came during the member for Brand’s time. We find ourselves in the position today where there were problems that had been hidden, and those opposite want to continue to hide them. However, our agenda is strong. On top of the $2.1 billion that we are spending this year in this particular area of government activity, there is a further $1.06 billion, which will be confirmed through the budget processes, for initiatives that back those who are in and entering the trades that are relevant to them. So, from 1 July, first year apprentices—these are apprentices in these areas of trade skills shortage—will be able to access a $500 tax free initiative that they will be able to keep. We recognise that there are costs involved in the early days—the first and second years of an apprenticeship. There is also the $800 tool kit allowance. All these initiatives are positive.
