Australia should enhance its travel advisory system by ensuring that travel agents are required to dispense travel advisories at the point at which travel arrangements are made. We are concerned, also, about the vulnerability of soft Australian targets overseas. We believe that a better strategy is necessary for providing protection for such targets. These elements form part of an overall integrated comprehensive regional counter-terrorism strategy for Australia, together with emergency response strategies and with capacity building in other related areas. As we approach legislation such as we have before us in the parliament at present I call on the government to take seriously the challenge which terrorism represents for Australian interests at home and in the region so that these challenges can now be met. (Time expired)

talker.name: Pyne, Chris, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing
talker.name: Mr PYNE

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank all the members for their contributions to this second reading debate. On behalf of the Attorney-General, who could not be in the House this afternoon, I would particularly like to thank the member for Barton, the member for Forrest and the member for Griffith, who made contributions of varying quality to the second reading debate. Of course, the member for Forrest’s was the best contribution to the debate. The member for Griffith and the member for Barton made useful, workmanlike contributions.

speech.para: The National Security Information Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 adds another dimension to the current protections for security sensitive information. Late last year the parliament passed legislation to protect information that may affect our national security if disclosed in federal criminal proceedings. That legislation targets the increasingly common evidential use of classified material in prosecutions for terrorist offences. The current bill provides similar protections for classified material in civil proceedings. Parties have sought to use such material in a wide range of civil cases, including family law and accident compensation proceedings. As with criminal proceedings, it is important that parties can use classified information without risk to our national security.

The bill introduces a regime for protecting security sensitive information in civil proceedings that broadly follows the regime in federal criminal proceedings. One main difference is the ability of the parties to apply for security clearances to gain access to security sensitive information. This was not an option in criminal proceedings, where defendants accused of terrorist offences are unlikely to receive such a clearance. In contrast, parties to civil proceedings are more likely to be self-represented and are also more likely to be eligible for a security clearance. When introducing the bill the Attorney-General advised the parliament that where a self-represented litigant in a civil matter is refused an appropriate security clearance, that individual would be eligible to apply for financial assistance under the non-statutory special circumstances scheme. I would now like to present new guidelines which specifically refer to this scheme.

The assistance would be subject to the Attorney-General, or his or her delegate, being satisfied that the individual would suffer financial hardship if the application were refused. The guidelines provide that successful applicants would receive financial assistance for the legal costs and related expenses of engaging a security cleared legal representative to attend the closed hearing and any related appeal. In this way the government is alleviating the costs of complying with the bill.

The government has also included provisions in the bill to protect the interests of parties. In making an order about disclosing information or calling a witness, subclause 38L(7) of the bill requires a court to consider whether the exclusion of information or a witness would have a substantial adverse effect on the substantive hearing in the proceeding. This means that the court must consider the effect of the order on both parties to the proceeding. Even if the court initially determines that the order would not have a substantial adverse effect, clause 19 states that the court can still stay the proceedings if it later finds otherwise. The court has an inherent jurisdiction to stay proceedings to prevent an injustice. The bill does not change this common law position. The bill makes it clear that where the court has made an order under subclause 38L, this inherent jurisdiction will not be affected. These measures demonstrate how the government is continuing to protect Australia’s national security without compromising the integrity of our legal system.

Since introducing the bill I have become aware of a drafting error that could lead to a misrepresentation of the term ‘civil proceeding’ as used in the legislation. For that reason I will shortly be moving an amendment to the bill to clarify the meaning of ‘civil proceeding’. I commend the bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

talker.name: Pyne, Chris, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing
talker.name: Mr PYNE

talk.start.para: —I present a supplementary explanatory memorandum to the bill and I move the government amendment:

item.para: Schedule 1, item 11, page 6 (lines 5 to 7), omit “federal criminal proceeding, and includes a contempt proceeding in relation to another civil proceeding or a federal criminal proceeding”, substitute “criminal proceeding”.

quote.para: [definition of civil proceeding]

speech.para: The National Security Information Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 was introduced into parliament on 10 March 2005. As foreshadowed earlier, the amendment I am moving rectifies a drafting error that could lead to a misinterpretation of the term ‘civil proceeding’ as used in the bill. Item 1 amends schedule 1, item 11 of the bill to remove the references to a federal criminal proceeding and to a contempt proceeding. ‘Civil proceeding’ will mean any proceeding in a Commonwealth, state or territory court except a criminal proceeding.

Omitting the word ‘federal’ corrects a drafting oversight that may have meant that a civil proceeding under the bill could include a criminal proceeding under a state or territory law. The intention underlying the initial inclusion of the wording relating to contempt was to ensure that where contempt was not an ordinary criminal offence created by statute but within the inherent power of the court to punish, it should be treated as a civil proceeding. On further consideration it is apparent that statutory contempt offences will fall within the definition of a criminal proceeding under the National Security Information Criminal Proceedings Act 2004. By contrast, contempt punishable under a court’s inherent powers will fall outside the definition of a criminal proceeding and would therefore constitute a civil proceeding. The reference to a contempt proceeding in the definition of civil proceeding is therefore unnecessary.
Question agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

motionnospeech.name: Mr PYNE
motionnospeech.role: —Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing)

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

debateinfo.title: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The purpose of the bill before the House is to abolish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The bill, which is largely identical to the bill passed by the House of Representatives and considered by the Senate in June 2004, is part of a major reform of the Australian government’s approach to Indigenous affairs.
The bill does one thing: it abolishes ATSIC. The bulk of the Australian government’s reforms to Indigenous affairs are proceeding independently of this bill.

In June 2004, the bill was referred to the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Indigenous Affairs. The committee reported back on 8 March 2005 saying that the abolition of ATSIC was a ‘fait accompli’. The delay in abolishing ATSIC has already cost the taxpayer around $2 million in commissioners’ salaries.

Significant changes to the way in which services are delivered to Indigenous Australian people have already been introduced. A quiet revolution has been under way since 1 July 2004, involving a radical new approach which will see Indigenous people empowered and taking control of their own destiny.

As a government, we have no intention of repeating the failed ATSIC experiment. ATSIC elections cost between $7 million and $9 million and annual remuneration for commissioners alone costs the taxpayer almost $3 million and a further $1 million for travel expenses. No-one could sensibly argue that there are not far better ways to spend that sort of money to benefit Indigenous people. We are culpable if we do not direct every available dollar to the welfare, needs and assistance of Aboriginal communities as they find new ways for self-reliance and independence.
The National Indigenous Council is not a replacement to ATSIC. It is a very different sort of body. It is not a representative body—its members were selected for their expertise.

They will not be the only group that the government will take advice from. There are numerous representative bodies and committees at the national level that will continue to express their views. Other Indigenous leaders will do so also—and we will listen.

Some senior Indigenous Australians are discussing the development of their own national representative body. If such a body emerges, it will be theirs—governments should not interfere by imposing a statutory model.

Indeed many of the submissions to the Senate select committee said that unlike ATSIC, which was a European construct, representative Indigenous bodies should be developed by Indigenous people themselves.

At the regional level we are working with state and territory governments, regional councils and a range of Indigenous organisations and communities to establish new regional representative arrangements. We recognise that different models are likely to emerge to suit different regions and jurisdictions.

But we do not want these representative and advisory bodies to prevent us from dealing directly with local families and communities. Our approach to shared responsibility agreements, based on a 20- to 30-year community vision, will be the vehicle for that.

All these measures have been put in place independently of the bill before the House. Most of the provisions of the bill are consequential to the abolition of ATSIC or put in place transitional or other provisions arising from the abolition of ATSIC.

This includes the transfer of the Regional Land Fund to the Indigenous Land Corporation and of ATSIC’s Housing Fund and Business Development Program to Indigenous Business Australia. Other land and property assets will be divested to Indigenous interests prior to the abolition of ATSIC or will be transferred to the Indigenous Land Corporation or Indigenous Business Australia for divestment or use for the benefit of Indigenous people.

The Office of Evaluation and Audit, OEA, which audits ATSIC programs, will audit the full range of Australian government Indigenous specific programs. It will continue to investigate the performance of bodies that obtain funding from Indigenous specific programs.

The bill that was introduced in the Senate in December last year includes a few minor changes to the previous bill in order to take into account the passage of time and to clarify some specific provisions.

The bill now before the House includes amendments moved by the Australian Labor Party. The opposition amendments include delaying the abolition of regional councils to 1 January 2006. The government rejects that amendment.

The bill before the House includes three amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. The amendments would limit the power of the minister to give general directions to Indigenous Business Australia, which is taking over some of ATSIC’s programs; insert a right to seek review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions by Indigenous Business Australia to refuse a business loan; and, require the Minister for the Environment and Heritage to consult an Indigenous advisory committee and an Indigenous expert on the Australian Heritage Council about proposals which could impact on Indigenous heritage values. We cannot accept these amendments because they are contrary to the intent of the bill. Accordingly, I will be moving during the consideration in detail stage to remove both the Labor Party’s and the Australian Democrats’ amendments from the bill. I will give quite detailed explanations of the bases for the government’s rejection of these amendments. It is not appropriate in a second reading speech to canvass these matters in detail, but I look forward to the debate at the time of the consideration in detail.

I trust that the opposition will now fulfil the commitment given on its behalf by the former leader of the Labor Party, the former member for Werriwa, to abolish ATSIC and allow the expeditious passage of the bill so a new era of dealing with Indigenous communities at a formal consultative level at least can begin to gather steam in the interests of Indigenous people especially. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Leave granted for second reading debate to continue immediately.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak to the second reading of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2005. Labor will be supporting the second reading of the bill but we will be moving our own second reading amendment. This bill formally abolishes ATSIC. However, it is important to acknowledge up front that the abolition of ATSIC is already an administrative fait accompli. The opposition agree with the government that major changes are required in the form of national representation for Australia’s Indigenous people, but that is essentially where the agreement ends. We fundamentally disagree with the government’s new arrangements and its approach to implementing them. Labor have a firm policy in support of a national Indigenous representative body—and when we say that we mean a representative body, not a phoney or fake advisory council that operates in secret.

speech.para: The government’s new National Indigenous Council is not chosen by Indigenous people and does not represent them in any meaningful way that we would all understand as being a basic form of representative democracy. This is doubly sad, given that the government’s new administrative arrangements are in such disarray. I will be moving a second reading amendment, as I have indicated, in line with that accepted by the Senate which highlights Labor’s concerns with the government’s approach. The government’s approach to Indigenous representation and self-determination is crystal clear. Its attitude to ATSIC and towards Indigenous Australians was clearly articulated in 1988, when the bill to establish ATSIC was first introduced into parliament. The ATSIC Bill was heavily amended by the opposition of the day, now the government. The debate in the Senate lasted for some 40 hours. At the time, the bill was the most amended by an opposition in the history of the Australian parliament. It is worth reflecting on some of the remarks made at the time by the now Prime Minister, John Howard. On 11 April 1989, when in opposition, Mr Howard told the House:

quote.para: ... if the Government wants to divide Australian against Australian, if it wants to create a black nation within the Australian nation, it should go ahead with its ... (ATSIC) legislation ... In the process it will be doing a monumental disservice to the Australian community.

speech.para: He also said:

quote.para: The ATSIC legislation strikes at the heart of the unity of the Australian people.
I say to the Minister that if the Government establishes this ATSIC legislation it will create more resentment and more division.
I ask the Government not to go ahead with the legislation.

talk.start.para: —Was he wrong?
—Indeed the Prime Minister was wrong, and if the minister is re-embracing those words he might specifically say so in his reply to the second reading debate.
—So you are defending ATSIC?

—As Senator Carr pointed out, John Howard’s words at the time of ATSIC’s establishment have proven to be nothing more than unfounded scaremongering, in terms of talking of establishing a nation within a nation and of dividing black against white. Yes, of course—to answer the minister—there have been obvious difficulties. There have been, indeed, more than difficulties; there have been real concerns. But in terms of your fundamental approach and your fundamental recognition of basic rights of representation and basic principles of democratic representation, those words indeed were scaremongering. If the minister wants to adopt them, we will be particularly interested.

speech.para: Who can forget the great act of reconciliation in the year 2000, when hundreds of thousands of Australians walked across bridges in this country to support the cause of reconciliation between Australia’s Indigenous and non-Indigenous citizens—walking across bridges being, of course, so tremendously symbolic of building bridges between the traditional owners and occupiers of our land and Australian citizens. Far from being divided one against another, black and white Australians came together in pursuit of true reconciliation. Unfortunately, it is now the government, in pushing its assimilation agenda, that has produced division and resentment, as the minister’s recent interjection in this debate has proven. It has done so without even making progress in addressing the ‘practical’ issue of Indigenous disadvantage, which unfortunately is still a shame that the Australian people must recognise and, with our resources, address.

During its time in government, the coalition has used ATSIC as a convenient scapegoat for all the problems in Indigenous service delivery. Indeed, the evidence presented throughout the Senate committee inquiry confirmed that ATSIC has often taken the blame for the broader failure of both Commonwealth and state government programs. We recognise that state governments of both persuasions could do better in this area, as well as the Commonwealth. But, at the end of the day, what we provide in terms of redressing what is unfortunately still an embarrassment to this nation means that, without fear or favour, you have to get stuck into both sides of politics. These include in areas such as education and health, for which ATSIC has no responsibility and in which mainstream programs have been letting Indigenous people down. The reality is that, despite the restraints placed on it, ATSIC has managed many successful programs. Despite its faults, ATSIC and its regional councils have demonstrated that Indigenous self-determination can be a powerful force for community and economic development.

There are many examples of Indigenous controlled programs that have succeeded. This is in line with the experience of other nations which have been far more successful than Australia in addressing indigenous disadvantage through self-determination—the very concept that the government consistently denigrates. Unfortunately, this government refuses to learn the lessons of Indigenous success, preferring to paint all Indigenous controlled programs as corrupt failures. Now ATSIC’s successful programs are to be mainstreamed. Whether they can maintain their unique features and, more importantly, their effectiveness remains to be seen, but the evidence so far does not give grounds for optimism.

Under the auspices of ATSIC, the Community Development Employment Projects scheme established in the 1970s continued to grow and develop. The CDEP provides meaningful work for thousands of Indigenous people within their own communities and supports vital community development and cultural activities. Its essential character is now under threat as a result of its move to the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations. In February of this year, Minister Andrews released a discussion paper on the future of CDEP. The discussion paper is a perfect example of the government’s failure to learn from success and its desire to adopt a so-called clean-slate approach to Indigenous policy. The paper says that, under the new arrangements, CDEP organisations will benefit from the assistance and experience of other employment and business services. There is no proposal to ask successful CDEPs whether, for instance, they would be in a position to mentor others to follow their successful examples. There is no proposed mechanism to support any form of sharing of best practice among CDEPs.

The government’s approach to consultation with Indigenous people about issues of critical importance to them is also demonstrated by its CDEP consultations. Following the release of the paper, Mr Andrews’ department immediately launched a four-day whistlestop tour of Australia allegedly to consult with Indigenous people and service providers. From what Labor has been told, departmental officials were able to offer very few answers in response to the questions and concerns of the participants who effectively had no real option in the consultation process. Indigenous communities, some of whom only get mail deliveries once a week, were then given a month to respond to the discussion paper. One month for remote communities during the wet season becomes particularly ridiculous when you realise the minimum community consultation period in the ACT, with its well-educated population and geographically small area, is six weeks. But, of course, it turns out that, like the abolition of ATSIC, the changes to CDEP are also a fait accompli anyway, so that casts doubt on the genuineness of that consultation process.

CDEP organisations have to submit expressions of interest for running the program under the new arrangements just four days after the closing date for submissions—and those four days are the Easter weekend. This approach to so-called consultation is entirely consistent with the development of its arrangements to replace ATSIC. Throughout the inquiry by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Indigenous Affairs, Indigenous participants told the committee that their voices had not been listened to in terms of recognising and respecting the dignity of the traditional owners of our country. That is indeed concerning.

All of the above is not to say that ATSIC was without fault. As we have recognised, as I think people of objective mind have recognised, like the government’s $1.4 million review the Senate committee identified a number of problems with ATSIC’s structure and operation. But these issues could be addressed to make a replacement national representative structure for Indigenous people a success. That is clearly what Indigenous Australians want to see. Professor Dodson, in evidence to the Senate inquiry and in relation to the national Indigenous leaders meeting which was held in Adelaide in 2004, said:

quote.para: ... the most significant point of agreement—overwhelming agreement; there was not one dissenter—was the need to maintain a national representative Indigenous voice. Participants at the meeting stressed that they—we, if you like; Indigenous Australians—should elect for themselves who would represent them at a national level.

speech.para: That is not an unreasonable request by any means. The Senate committee recommended that the government provide active support and funding for the formation of a national Indigenous elected representative body and provide it with ongoing funding.

Labor calls on the government to heed the cause of Indigenous Australians, and indeed all fair-minded people, and to negotiate with Indigenous people to establish a new national Indigenous representative body based on sound democratic principles and self-representation. Labor will be actively consulting with Indigenous people about the new representative arrangements that they want. It will be listening to what Indigenous Australians have to say about how they want to be represented and will respect the dignity of those representations that will be made as part of its consultation processes. As I said at the beginning of this speech, while Labor is committed to the development of a new national representative voice for Indigenous Australians, it accepts that the abolition of ATSIC is a fait accompli.

However, Labor has moved an amendment in the Senate in relation to regional councils and that amendment is reflected in the bill that is now before the House. The opposition amendment extends the life of the ATSIC regional councils by six months—in line with recommendation 4.3 of the report of the Senate select committee tabled in parliament on 8 March 2005. Labor talked to the government about this proposal at some length over quite a period of time. Initially it appeared that the government was going to be reasonable about this, and there are a number of reasonable government senators who I suspect are quite uncomfortable about how the government’s approach to this legislation has developed. The opposition’s reasoning in dealing with the matter was absolutely sound and absolutely moderate. The irony of the situation is that the existence of strong regional frameworks is going to be essential for the government to achieve the kind of effective practical partnerships that it says it wants with Indigenous people.

The government’s own policy approach of shared responsibility depends on these partnerships having credibility among Indigenous people. The government’s policy depends on having a credible regional body with which it can negotiate regional partnership agreements which are supposed to provide the framework for the community-level shared responsibility agreements. The Senate select committee inquiry uncovered a remarkable degree of uncertainty within the bureaucracy about how shared responsibility agreements will operate. It also found deep concern and a substantial degree of confusion in Indigenous communities about the abolition of ATSIC regional structures, how they are going to be replaced and how the new arrangements will work.

The Murdi Paaki Regional Council is one of the most successful regional councils and one that is working hard to ensure that a sound regional structure remains after the commission has gone. While this western New South Wales area has received praise from the government for its efforts, Mr Sam Jeffries from the council expressed serious concerns in the Senate committee hearings based on his own experience. He said:

quote.para: The Murdi Paaki experience demonstrates that the best way to connect government service delivery for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is through institutions of Indigenous representation, advocacy and participation which have legislative endorsement and accountability. Regional and community governance are the leadership tools that return responsibility to us, lift us out of the poverty trap and break the generational cycle that has handed down a legacy of social dysfunction.

speech.para: They are words which I will not read again; they are on the record and they really cut to the chase. We would focus the government precisely on those comments by a person who, clearly, is practical, is a person of competence and is a person of achievement in genuinely representing the interests of Indigenous Australians. The government’s approach is to wait for new structures to ‘emerge’—to use their term—without putting resources into communities to support their consultation process.

During the Senate select committee hearings it became clear that regional councils which have been working on developing new representative models that suit their communities need more time. These communities are willing to do the hard yards but they cannot do it without support. You would think that the government would embrace the continuation of a structure which provides certainty and enables consultation at the regional level while the new arrangements are still being bedded down. Instead, the government’s form of consultation really seems to be requiring these bodies to negotiate about terms of surrender rather than about something that is going to genuinely work in these communities.

A key reason for extending the life of the regional councils is to ensure some certainty and stability while regions and communities endeavour to establish new arrangements. It is for this reason that the amendment includes a clause which prevents current ATSIC commissioners from returning to positions in regional councils and being elected to the position of chair. This was a refinement discussed with the government and reflects how seriously Minister Vanstone was considering supporting this amendment before she was overruled by the Prime Minister’s office.

In conclusion, Labor stand beside Australia’s Indigenous people in their struggle for social justice. We as Australians collectively have a responsibility to deliver that. We will work with Indigenous Australians to achieve the restoration of a national representative structure. We will respect their dignity as the traditional owners of this land. We will recognise our responsibilities to them. Labor’s second reading amendment expresses our concern about the direction of Indigenous policy under the Howard government’s proposal, which is essentially, as the minister indicated in his interjection, one that is still frightfully divisive. I now move the opposition’s second reading amendment, which is:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:

item.para: notes:

item.label: (a)
item.para: that the Government’s ‘practical reconciliation’ agenda has failed to improve outcomes for Indigenous Australians;

item.label: (b)
item.para: that there is no evidence that mainstreaming of service delivery will in any way help to address Indigenous disadvantage;

item.label: (c)
item.para: the Government’s failure to advance the goal of reconciliation between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians;

item.label: (d)
item.para: the Government’s failure to negotiate a treaty with Indigenous Australians or to guarantee self-determination for Australia’s Indigenous people; and

item.label: (e)
item.para: that the abolition of Indigenous representative organisations will serve to further marginalise Australia’s Indigenous citizens;
condemns the Government for failing to:

item.label: (a)
item.para: consult or negotiate with Indigenous Australians on the provisions of the bill;

item.label: (b)
item.para: develop a new legislative and administrative model that restores the right of Indigenous Australians to be responsible for their own future, despite the international evidence demonstrating that this approach delivers the best practical outcomes;
supports the implementation of new legislative and administrative arrangements that restore responsibility and opportunity for Indigenous Australians; and
calls on the Government to:

item.label: (a)
item.para: guarantee that Indigenous communities will be genuine partners in the policy development and the delivery of services;

item.label: (b)
item.para: ensure that a properly resourced regional representative structure is developed according to the preferences of Indigenous communities; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: consult with Indigenous people for the purpose of negotiating the establishment of a new national Indigenous representative body whose members are chosen by Indigenous people”.

talk.start.para: (Hon. BK Bishop)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I am very pleased to be able to support the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2005 and I certainly oppose the amendment just moved by the honourable member for Barton. I do not think that in 2005 any of us should feel particularly proud of the situation of our Indigenous people in this country. There is no doubt that over the years Indigenous people have fallen behind the general community. However, since 1996 when the government was elected there has been substantial progress to improve outcomes.

speech.para: I think that traditionally in Australia there seems to be an attitude that to throw money at a problem is in some way going to solve it. But it is pretty clear when you look at the level of Indigenous disadvantage—in infant mortality, housing, education and so on—that money alone is simply not going to solve the problem. Personally, I believe that there has been too much emphasis on process and insufficient emphasis on outcome. Quite appropriately, both sides of politics have endeavoured to involve Indigenous people in the decision-making process, but our focus always ought to be on outcomes and not on process.

I spoke to a Queensland medical specialist some time ago who used to run quite a small program which did not cost very much and was designed to improve Indigenous eye care. It was taken over by an Indigenous bureaucracy. The program cost more and achieved less. While as a community we might feel that we are salving our collective consciences by assigning the decision-making process to Indigenous people, I believe the ultimate aim ought to be to redress Indigenous disadvantage, not simply make us all feel great at having passed the buck to Indigenous people to make the decisions.

The government have very real reason to be proud of the many achievements that we have gained through Indigenous programs. We have introduced new initiatives and there has been a very strong focus on practical reconciliation in the key areas of health, housing, employment and education. The government are entitled to reflect on our record and be proud, but there is of course much more to be done. The community is particularly keen to see accountability for money spent on Indigenous programs at the same level as the community demands for other government expenditure. A lot of the haemorrhaging headlines we have seen in relation to ATSIC make it very difficult for any government to get the necessary community support for spending the level of dollars that we need to spend to redress Indigenous disadvantage. I think the community is quite happy for money to be spent on improving the situation of our Indigenous people as long as the community and Indigenous people are seen to be getting value for money. When we read stories of theft of money from government programs and of ATSIC allocating government resources for Indigenous people to benefit individual commissioners, the situation plays into the hands of those people who do not have the interests of Indigenous people at heart.

That is why I very strongly support this bill. This bill is not about removing Indigenous people’s opportunity to make decisions; it is all about improving Indigenous outcomes. I am pleased that the opposition does accept that ATSIC has had its day. In fact, when you look at what people have said about ATSIC over the years, it is fairly clear that ATSIC has been a failed experiment. I would like to draw the attention of honourable members to an editorial in the Australian newspaper of 24 February this year. It is quite a long editorial. It is headed ‘Death throes of ATSIC a disgrace’ and in effect it is quite critical of ATSIC and the fact that, even though the Howard government’s new Indigenous council has made a promising start, ‘it is being starved of oxygen by an ATSIC sideshow that is costing taxpayers $65,000 a week in commissioners’ wages’. The editorial goes on to state:

quote.para: Meanwhile, the problems in Aboriginal communities—of hygiene, disease, substance abuse and sexual violence—continue to grow worse, just as they have done throughout ATSIC’s 15-year existence. ATSIC has gone from a failed experiment to a shamed one. Will Labor finally do the right thing when the bill to abolish ATSIC returns to the Senate next month?

speech.para: Like many honourable members, I have a very high personal regard for the honourable member for Barton. I think he is a person of great individual integrity. He is a person whom I respect tremendously. However, I am disappointed that he has moved this motion in the House to extend the life of regional councils. The delay in passing the ATSIC bill has caused a great deal of confusion and damage to Indigenous Australians. We have a situation whereby the ALP is seeking to extend the regional councils by six months. This will simply cause more confusion and further hurt Indigenous Australians.

Indigenous Australians and others are aware that these councils were to finish up on 1 July this year. Some councils have been active and replacement arrangements are in place. An extension would mean that these plans would be disrupted. Other regional councils have dropped the ball and we have a situation where regional councils do not really have a high mandate from Indigenous people, and I am told that only one in five eligible voters actually bother to vote. You could imagine what people would say about the mandate of the federal government of the day if only 20 per cent of Australians bothered to vote at the ballot box. The regional councils’ job was to produce regional plans. A lot of effort went into these but many regional councils have complained that no-one reads them or takes any notice of them. We saw in-fighting in the ATSIC board. This has also extended in many cases to regional councils, and the government wants Indigenous people to construct their own regional bodies if they actually want them.

I point out that since 1996 the government has a lot to be proud of but that there is still more to be done. The proportion of Indigenous people who own or are purchasing their own home has increased from one in four in the 1970s to one in three today. The proportion of Indigenous students completing high school has quadrupled since the 1970s. The infant mortality rate has been cut by more than three-quarters, from up to 20 times the non-Indigenous rate to three times that rate. That is still too high but it is a very substantial improvement. The Aboriginal imprisonment rate relative to that of non-Aborigines has been declining, as have average per capita deaths in prison. So while there is more to be done, much has been achieved and it is the responsibility of the government to try to bring about an outcome so that we are able to build on the successes that we already have. The government has taken the initiative in reducing Indigenous disadvantage. A record $2.9 billion will be spent this year on Indigenous specific programs alone. The ALP are always talking about apologies, but one could really ask what they have done in a practical sense. The Australian government has provided $120 million for real initiatives, including counselling and parenting programs, language and cultural programs, and the link-up network, a record preservation project. These are all meaningful outcomes. The opposition simply like to lambaste the government, accusing us of not listening, being dogmatic or moving forward in a way that Indigenous people do not want. I think it is important to focus on outcome. It is pretty clear that the opposition have not been listening properly. We are not abolishing special programs; we are putting in place machinery to make the mainstream agencies take up their required responsibilities. Many of the Indigenous programs that mainstream agencies now manage will benefit Indigenous people in the future.

It is important to recognise that this bill is a very vital step forward in the progress of Indigenous people. I am someone who is passionate about outcomes for Indigenous people. I am not proud of what we have achieved as a society with respect to our Indigenous people over the last 200 years; in fact, we should be ashamed. However, this government has achieved much. It is a work in progress and the abolition of ATSIC is an important step in this direction.

I gather that the party whips have agreed to limit the amount of time for members to speak on this bill to 10 minutes, so it is probably appropriate at this stage that I commend the bill to the House. I encourage the opposition not to persist with their second reading amendment, because I think the future of our Indigenous people is far too important to be politicised. It is something where we should be working hand in hand to improve outcomes. I know that on both sides of politics we passionately desire improved outcomes. This bill is a step in that direction. I thank honourable members for their support because it really is vital in 2005 that we continue the progress that we have made. ATSIC, of course, has failed. We need to find better outcomes and this bill is an important step in that direction. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —Less than three weeks ago I met with a group of young Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians in Newcastle to mark the 40th anniversary of the 1965 freedom ride, when a busload of Sydney university students, led by Charlie Perkins, went on a journey through New South Wales to expose the level of discrimination against Indigenous people. One of the main aims of the 1965 freedom ride was to highlight examples of segregation, including at public swimming pools, picture theatres and pubs where Aboriginal people were refused entry. The 1965 freedom ride helped to bring the ingrained discrimination and racism in New South Wales country towns to the attention of the wider Australian public and was part of a broader push for Aboriginal civil rights taking place across the country.

speech.para: To celebrate the 40th anniversary of the original freedom ride, ReconciliACTION filled a bus with young people passionate about reconciliation and retraced that original freedom ride journey whilst making a documentary about the experience. The Freedom Ride 2005 bus left from the University of Sydney on Saturday, 12 February. It then travelled north-west through Wellington, Dubbo, Gulargambone, Walgett, Moree, Boggabilla, Toomelah, Goondiwindi, Inverell, Tingha and the Myall Creek memorial to Lismore, Bowraville, Kempsey, Taree, Purfleet, Newcastle and then, of course, back to Sydney.

I had the privilege of meeting this group of passionate young Australians when they came to Newcastle and it was refreshing to hear them talk about their views of what they had learnt and their enthusiasm for shaping a better future. The bus returned to a celebratory homecoming in Redfern on Saturday, 26 February. The aim of the Freedom Ride 2005 was to get Australians talking again about the racism of today as well as to connect with young people across New South Wales to find out their views on how Australia can move forward in reconciliation. The House can be assured that these young Australians, like those they met on their journey, do not support the government’s notion of practical reconciliation or the soon-to-be-complete lack of any national representative body for Indigenous Australians.

Given the historical significance of both the 1965 and 2005 freedom rides and their special place within the history of struggles for Aboriginal rights in Australia, it is with great sadness that, less than three weeks after the completion of Freedom Ride 2005, the Australian parliament is being asked to abolish the only body that currently provides national representation for Indigenous people, with no plans for a replacement representative body—and I emphasise ‘representative’. It is not the abolition that is the main issue to me, to my constituents and to people concerned about reconciliation but the failure of this government to assist Indigenous people to determine the replacement body and their new form of representation. That is something of great regret.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2005 will abolish ATSIC and, while the opposition agree that there needs to be a major revamp of the form of national representation of Australia’s Indigenous people, that is where we part company with the government. We strongly disagree with the government’s approach to implementing its new arrangements and moved a series of amendments in the Senate last night which have the support of the minor parties to improve this otherwise dismal and backward-looking piece of legislation. It certainly inspires no hope. Labor support the principle of a national Indigenous representative body, and this support is reflected in our policy. Regrettably, the government’s new National Indigenous Council is not a body chosen by Indigenous people to represent them at a national level. Although Labor have commended the expertise of members of the new NIC, we have also warned that they have no mandate to represent Indigenous Australians. The NIC’s only function is to advise the government, not to represent Indigenous people. It does not, and therefore indeed cannot, speak on behalf of all Indigenous Australians.

It appears that the NIC members are accountable to no-one except the person who chose them—the Prime Minister. In the wake of ATSIC it is important to underline the fact that the NIC is not a legitimate alternative to ATSIC. It is not a national Indigenous representative body but rather an advisory group that the government may or may not take any notice of when it deliberates on Indigenous affairs in the future. Given that the government will very soon control both houses of parliament, it is scandalous that the only body able to provide advice on Indigenous issues to the government is one that the government has itself created without consulting Indigenous people or the Australian parliament. That is not best practice. It is certainly not something I have seen done with any other advisory group. The council comprises people appointed by the very same government that sets the parameters of its structure and operations. That certainly raises a conflict of interest. So much for the notion of providing advice without fear or favour! This is a sad day for democracy and an even sadder day for Indigenous affairs. Forget self-determination; apparently this government has no plans to replace ATSIC with another elected representative body and, in the interim period, has managed to reduce Indigenous decision making and participation in national affairs to mere consultation with a very select few.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —I suspend the sitting until 8 p.m. in order that I may present the address-in-reply to His Excellency the Governor-General at Government House. I shall be glad if the mover and seconder, together with other honourable members, will accompany me to present the address.

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 6.00 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: — I inform the House that, accompanied by honourable members, Mr Speaker waited today upon His Excellency the Governor-General at Government House and presented to him the address-in-reply to His Excellency’s speech on the opening of the first session of the 41st Parliament, agreed to by the House on 17 February 2005. His Excellency was pleased to make the following reply:

para.inline: Thank you for your address in reply.
It will be my pleasure and my duty to convey to Her Majesty the Queen the Message of Loyalty from the House of Representatives, to which the address gives expression.

debateinfo.title: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 2005

talk.start.para: —The bill before the House gives effect to the government’s decision to abolish ATSIC by amending the ATSIC Act 1989 to provide for the abolition of ATSIC and ATSIC regional councils. Apart from concentrating much of the power previously vested in ATSIC in the hands of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and her/his delegate, the bill makes a number of so-called consequential amendments to the act.

speech.para: We have, of course, seen this bill in a slightly different form in the House last year. Labor did not support the passage of the legislation then, because of our concerns about the government’s plans for administration of Indigenous affairs in the post-ATSIC environment. Accordingly, Labor supported the establishment of a Senate inquiry—the findings of which I will turn to later in this speech.

But for now it is clear that the Howard government is focused on the past as usual, emphasising assimilation through the so-called ‘mainstreaming’ of services for Indigenous people. That ‘mainstreaming’ has long failed to address Indigenous disadvantage in Australia seems not to bother this government at all. Indeed, ATSIC has long been blamed by this government for failing to improve Aboriginal health in Australia, despite the fact that Aboriginal health services were mainstreamed more than a decade ago, with very little to show by way of improved health outcomes for Indigenous people.

Aboriginal people still have a life expectancy 20 years less than the Australian average. The death rates of Indigenous people from diabetes are eight to 12 times higher than the average Australian rate, and 20 per cent of Indigenous children—55 per cent in some areas—have early stages of trachoma. You cannot blame ATSIC for these outcomes. Aboriginal health services were ‘mainstreamed’ 10 years ago.

ATSIC was established by the Hawke Labor government and came into operation in 1990. It combined for the first time ever in the one organisation the representative and program delivery roles of previous bodies. The Hawke Labor government gave decision-making power over Aboriginal affairs to Aboriginal people. This was a bold innovation in Indigenous affairs some 15 years ago.

And who can forget Paul Keating’s landmark Redfern speech, when he launched the Year of the World’s Indigenous People in December 1992? As Prime Minister, Keating spoke passionately about the newly established ATSIC. He explained how ‘ATSIC emerged from the vision of Indigenous self-determination and self-management’ and described how ‘all over Australia, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities are taking charge of their own lives’. The speech was inspirational and delivered a positive agenda for the future of Indigenous affairs in Australia.

But here we are, some 13 years later, with a Prime Minister and coalition government intent on destroying any remnants of Aboriginal self-determination and self-management that have managed to survive their ongoing attacks since coming to office. While the 1990s can be described as a time of hope for Indigenous people, this current period is perhaps best described as a full-frontal attack on Indigenous rights, hopes and aspirations.

The Prime Minister has always opposed the existence of ATSIC. During the parliamentary debate on ATSIC’s establishment, the then opposition leader, John Howard, argued against the establishment of a separate representative body and service delivery organisation, claiming that the creation of ‘a parliament within the Australian community for Aboriginal people’ was a ‘misguided notion’, the pursuit of which would be a ‘monumental disservice to the Australian community’. But history will eventually show that it is in fact the Howard government that has proven to be a ‘monumental disservice’ to the Australian community and to Indigenous Australians in particular.

Following instructions from the Howard government in 1996, an independent company of auditors found very little fault with the financial affairs and accountabilities of ATSIC, but the Howard government opted to cut $470 million from ATSIC’s budget over the next four years and slashed programs by up to 30 per cent. And now we wonder why the government have some concerns about performance! Finally, the government imposed financial constraints on ATSIC, dictating the exact purpose for which over 80 per cent of their budget was to be used.

It is remarkable that in the face of unrelenting attacks from this government ATSIC, and the ATSIC regional councils in particular, have continued to manage a number of successful programs. For example, under the auspices of ATSIC, the Community Development Employment Projects scheme has grown enormously. In Newcastle, Youloe-Ta, our local registered CDEP, is funded for 266 participants at present. It has grown, since being set up by Yarnteen in 1993, and has continued to have outstanding outcomes. One particular success of Yarnteen was the granting of $100,000—not by the Australian government but by Microsoft USA—to network all CDEPs across New South Wales. It is an outstanding program and an outstanding achievement.

In our region, Yarnteen are caught up in this legislative problem. This new legislation poses severe difficulties for organisations such as Yarnteen. Yarnteen have been operating since 1991. Their aim is to become a full, free agent in their own development. As an organisation, they have always kept pace with change and reviewed the quality of their service delivery. I would say that, with the exception of economic self-sufficiency—and I want to raise that point—all their other objectives have been achieved.

In relation to Yarnteen’s enterprise development, we are talking about a very successful tourism venture; property investments based on advice from Indigenous Business Australia, Indigenous business development; programs to improve social wellbeing; a digital access strategy; leadership development; and partnership promotion. At the moment, they wish to expand into an education centre which would train people and provide great advances in employment opportunities for Indigenous people. But they are caught in a trap: there is a caveat on their loan held by ATSIC.

While they are seeking, and would be granted, a further loan to do that from the financial sector, the caveat stays in place on the loan they have with ATSIC. It is a loan for $1 million. They have actually paid off over $2 million in ATSIC loans ahead of time and they have never defaulted. They have opportunities now to keep investing in the future, but because of the quagmire created by this legislation and the government’s failure to anticipate the risk to all the good things that are happening out in regional Australia they are caught up in this and are prejudiced by this situation. One can only wonder whether that is the intention. These groups do aim for self-sufficiency and, unfortunately, have their hands tied. Success stories like these are not told by this government, and problems like that faced by Yarnteen are certainly not solved by this legislation.

ATSIC also administers the funding for the Aboriginal legal service in my area. Those legal services are seriously underfunded and cannot possibly meet the demands of the people in the Many Rivers zone. The equivalent of 2½ lawyers are available to meet the needs of 35,000 people in the whole of the Many Rivers region. But this government is now threatening to effectively mainstream Aboriginal legal services via a new tendering process. In New South Wales there are currently six regional ALSs that cover the whole of New South Wales and the ACT. They have been delivering quality, culturally appropriate legal services since 1997. The Many Rivers Aboriginal Legal Service has an office in my electorate of Newcastle. It provides a wide range of services, including specialist services for domestic violence that are highly regarded.

Labor is concerned that the government’s push to have legal services for Aboriginal people in New South Wales tendered out is very narrowly focused in that it does not take account of the full range of services currently provided by the existing legal services and it further reduces the employment and training opportunities for Aboriginal people in regional areas of New South Wales. Labor is, and I am, opposed to the tendering out of legal services for Aboriginal people.

The government’s program of dealing directly with local Indigenous communities by way of so-called ‘shared responsibility agreements’—SRAs—was not fully apparent at the time the abolition of ATSIC was announced. By the end of 2005 the government hopes to have 80 SRAs in place. But, as we discovered when the content of the draft SRA for the Mulan community in the Kimberley region of Western Australia was revealed, these agreements turn out not to be so shared after all but rather unbalanced and one-sided. As members of parliament, we deal every day with people —I think it is something like 7,000 a year in my office—who already find it difficult to negotiate through government departments, regulations and conditions. One wonders how remote communities would be able to equally negotiate genuine agreements.

Indigenous Australians must be able to reach genuine agreements with government, not be forced into coercive and patronising contracts. There is a stench of pious imposition and paternalism in SRAs. This government is telling Indigenous communities to choose between social rights and social responsibilities. I am not sure who has all the responsibilities, but the division does not seem quite right here. This government is telling Indigenous Australians that to obtain basic services they must meet conditions not imposed on others. That would be fine, I guess, if there was a guaranteed supply of clean water—if there were guaranteed supplies of the services that you and I take for granted every day of our lives. It does not seem right and it does not seem fair that a government would try to negotiate SRAs without any attempt at developing a level playing field and putting it in place for Indigenous people.

As a former school principal who has worked with Indigenous students, their families and their communities for many years, I know that this is not the way to effect change. Instead of forcing people into coercive contracts, why are we not making sure that Indigenous people have access to the services that they need for their families, for parenting, for raising children, for health care and for hygiene—things they are dependent on such as clean water and adequate housing. Decent jobs and lifelong learning would be a great start as well.

As was well demonstrated during the Senate inquiry, there is considerable concern about the degree to which responsibilities will be genuinely shared under the SRAs, whether obligations are genuinely agreed and genuinely mutual, the extent to which decisions are made on a genuinely informed basis and the extent to which the services under discussion in these agreements are discretionary or core entitlements of citizenship. There is also a concern that gains made in recent decades, such as land rights, will come under challenge.

Unfortunately, this bill does nothing to alleviate those concerns. The key messages arising from the evidence provided to the Senate committee were: anger and frustration at the lack of consultation with Indigenous people concerning the government’s new arrangements, in particular the fact that it has ignored the findings of its own $1.4 million review of ATSIC; concern that Indigenous representation is being removed, not only at the national level but particularly at the regional level, with no mechanism to establish or fund replacement regional structures—and I always believe in every field that local solutions are what work best, and if we do not aim for that with our Indigenous communities we are really going to have very little success; the lack of evidence that mainstreaming of service delivery is likely to lead to an improvement in outcomes for Indigenous people; concern over how ATSIC’s assets will be managed, and whether Indigenous control over significant cultural assets, such as the art collection, will be maintained, which obviously it will not; and concern over the speed with which the new arrangements have been implemented and the fact that they have so far led to more, rather than less, bureaucracy for Indigenous communities to deal with.

While the committee will make a number of recommendations relating to these issues, the key outcomes being sought are the extension of regional councils for a further six months, to 31 December 2005, to provide more opportunity for a smooth transition to new regional governance arrangements where these are under development—I would hope that such an outcome might help groups like Yarnteen find a financial solution that allows them to progress and continue with their outstanding programs—and the establishment of a Senate standing committee on Indigenous affairs. I call on the government to support Labor’s amendment so that the thousands of Aboriginal organisations like Yarnteen can have some certainty for their future. Indigenous Australians deserve much more from this government, but agreeing to these amendments would at least be a good start.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased this evening to be able to speak on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2005. It gives me the opportunity to make a few brief comments in support of this bill. Obviously, I reject the second reading amendment that has been moved by the member for Barton. It has obviously been foisted on him by the Left of his party and, as a result, he has moved it in this House. But we know that this is just tilting at windmills because ultimately, one way or another, this legislation will be passed.

speech.para: When the ATSIC Bill passed through the House under the Hawke government in November 1989, becoming law in 1990, and when ATSIC began functioning in 1990, ATSIC’s formation was described as a very bold experiment in the process and progress of Indigenous affairs and Aboriginal issues in this country, and it served a purpose in the intervening years. However, we reached a stage in the lead-up to 2004 where not only did the Aboriginal community and the wider community believe that ATSIC had failed the Aboriginal people of this country but also it was found to be an unworkable body which did not deliver to Aboriginal people. Just to put this in perspective, here in Canberra, where there are very few Aboriginal people, we had a bureaucracy of over 400 people—over 400 bureaucrats administering this huge body and massive amounts of money; it was $1.3 billion last year—working in a building in Woden. The notional amount of money out of that budget that ever reached Aboriginals on the ground was 8c in the dollar, which is not the way to serve Aboriginals and the community but the way to serve the Aboriginal bureaucrats and the ATSIC board themselves. A litany of cases have come before the courts and have been brought to media attention of ATSIC commissioners thwarting their power and responsibility, having served their own pockets in the promotion of themselves.

Last week two Aboriginal people came to see me in my electorate office—the Aboriginal elder of the Armadale area, Vivienne Hansen, and her husband, Mort. They said: ‘Mr Randall, if you think your politics are out of control, wait till you get involved in Aboriginal politics. They are the worst. You might engage in rough-and-tumble politics, but Aboriginal politics are brutal. As a result, we don’t believe the system has worked. We agree with the break-up of ATSIC because, ultimately, we believe we’re going to get a better deal for all Aboriginal people rather than just families and the nepotism which the ATSIC system eventually delivered.’ That is why many Aboriginal people themselves agreed with this break-up.

Many admirable people have led ATSIC. Lowitja O’Donoghue, for example, a very fine person, showed great leadership of the Aboriginal people. I think probably the most outstanding person was Gadil Djerr-kura, who was an icon to the Aboriginal people in his leadership, his decency and his own personal achievements in business and in the community. Mr Quartermaine, as the last ATSIC commissioner, has done a very good job. Probably the person who did most to bring ATSIC down was Geoff Clark, because of his recalcitrant behaviour. You only had to see that in the last few weeks where he has been involved in numerous cases. I will not go through them, but to take off with Nicky Winmar’s jumper—to take it down off the wall, decide to head off into the night with it and then get into some sort of a row with Nicky about whether it was the right jumper or not and who owned it—was the sort of bizarre behaviour that eventually brought discredit to ATSIC and those who led it. You just cannot allow something like that to continue. The community are on our side.

The former leader of the Labor Party, Mark Latham, for all his faults, agreed that ATSIC had run its course. When you look at the speakers list for this debate, it is interesting to see, other than the member for Barton, largely members of the Left of the Labor Party. My good friend over there, the member for Banks, would not shy away from the fact that he is a good paid-up member of the Left and, as a result, he is going to speak passionately on this bill and say, ‘We was all wronged on behalf of ATSIC!’ I will watch you on TV, Member for Banks, because I will hear an impassioned speech about how—

talk.start.para: —Stay in the chamber; don’t watch it on TV!

—No, I will watch it on TV, because then I can actually have a red wine while I am trying to enjoy myself watching you. At the end of the day, the member for Banks will do his job—and that is, as a paid-up member of the Left, to give an impassioned speech on this issue. Ultimately, the commission is to be replaced by a national Aboriginal advisory council, the National Indigenous Council, led by magistrate Sue Gordon—a Western Australian and a constituent of mine. Sue Gordon is a fine lady who has done some great things for Aboriginal people. Part of the so-called stolen generation in Western Australia and a former occupant of Sister Kate’s Home in Perth, she is somebody who has progressed beyond her whole background and given sensational leadership.

speech.para: Interestingly, when I spoke to the Hansens last week in my office about Aboriginal leadership and the advisory board, of which Adam Goodes and other notable Aboriginal people are members, they said, ‘Look, Don, these blackfellas that are heading up this board aren’t like us; they’re not grassroots, hands-on Aboriginals. But at the end of the day I suppose we’ve got to have somebody leading us, and we think that they’re not bad—but we wouldn’t mind having a bit more of an input into it.’ My response to the Hansens was: ‘You can have an input into it, because not only can you go to the likes of Sue Gordon, who is available to you to further advise the government, but there is nothing precluding you from applying to be a part of this advisory committee or some form of this advisory body.’ I understand that it is not a closed shop. In fact, at the end of the day, a broad church is welcome to give advice on behalf of the Aboriginal community to government.

I found it rather interesting that another paid-up member of the Left over there, the member for Newcastle, talks in all this ingratiating language of how ashamed she is and of ‘culturally appropriate legal services’ for the Aboriginal community. I would have thought we are all Australians, whether we are Chinese or we come from some other ethnic background. We all have cultural differences in the way we interpret the law and how we respond to it, but to say that you need special people and there are only the equivalent of 2½ people in her region that could do this I thought was a bit patronising when she was endeavouring to say that this whole issue was patronising.

I recommend to the House an article by the Australian’s editor-at-large, Paul Kelly, on Wednesday, 8 December 2004 headed ‘A new Indigenous politics—why Aboriginal leaders have veered right towards mutual obligation’. Nobody would claim that Paul Kelly was in any way biased or a friend of this government. He is considered to be someone in the media who is very balanced in his opinions. I need to read some of this article into Hansard because, in terms of the cultural change and the changes that are associated with this bill, it is very important that it be on the record:

quote.para: There is no better example of the transformation of our politics than the new joint position of Patrick Dodson and Noel Pearson that accepts mutual obligation as the essential step in improving the lives of indigenous Australians.
This has been driven not just by the convincing nature of John Howard’s fourth election victory but the failure of the progressive Left’s policy agenda over a generation.

speech.para: Did you hear that, member for Banks? The article continues:

quote.para: Howard is no longer fighting the culture war against Paul Keating. His indigenous policies are no longer defined by negatives: … refusing the legitimacy of elected bodies with the abolition of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.
This represents probably the most sweeping rethink since the 1967 referendum …
The aim is to terminate passive welfare delivery and substitute instead “shared responsibility agreements” between local communities and government.

speech.para: We know that we are going from 35 regions to 85 SRAs. It is in line with the thinking of many members of the coalition that, instead of top-down funding from the huge bureaucracy in Canberra that delivers 8c in the dollar to Aboriginals on the ground, we talk about bottom-up funding, in which funding is delivered to the regions and Aboriginals can determine their own future through the massive amount of funding that can go to 2½ per cent of the population for their betterment, advancement and welfare.

We know that Noel Pearson was not a great friend of this government. But he has seen the light—unlike the Socialist Left. Pearson has been a decisive influence on this policy. It was Pearson who set out the bedrock position in this argument. He said that we have to see the Howard prime ministership as an opportunity rather than a threat to Indigenous Australians. Good on you, Noel Pearson. You are doing something for your people. You are taking them forward rather than taking them back to the dinosaur age, which the Left would do.

The Prime Minister welcomed the Dodson-Pearson olive branch. There is goodwill in the government towards trying to find lasting and better solutions for underprivileged Aboriginal communities. But, as I said, the Prime Minister stressed that this policy was based on localism—bottom-up funding to the regions and local communities. As Paul Kelly’s article says:

quote.para: The point is that the policies of the progressive Left have collapsed—and the failure of these policies in relation to Australia’s most underprivileged minority is pivotal in its own right and prophetic for the course of politics.

speech.para: As I said, the Latham leadership was unable to turn the Labor Party’s position around. Remember that they went to the last election saying that Latham was the best thing since sliced bread. Now you cannot hear a whisper about him. But he was the one leading them forward. As Paul Kelly says:

quote.para: Labor’s crisis is that it is embarrassed by the progressive Left’s social agenda almost to the point of an identity. Now it is humiliated and rendered irrelevant …
Labor’s main problem is that the policies by which it has defined itself don’t work any more.

speech.para: I rest my case. At the end of the day, here is a chance to take the Aboriginal community forward through mainstreaming and provide an opportunity for Aboriginals throughout Australia to receive the best possible policy initiatives from this government. It will be opposed by those on the other side because they are in an ideological left-wing time warp, but I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —It is appropriate at the outset of my contribution to this debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2005 that I acknowledge the traditional owners of Canberra, the Ngunnawal people. I also want to acknowledge the presence in the gallery of ATSIC Commissioner Cliff Foley. History is written by the victors. Tonight we are presiding over the death throes of ATSIC. This legislation will bring ATSIC to a conclusion. It has taken nine years, but ATSIC’s fate was sealed when the Howard government was elected in March 1996. It did not take long. In the government’s first budget, in 1996, ATSIC’s budget was slashed by $470 million over four years. Many worthwhile programs hit the fence. With the election of this government, we were told that the government would determine the priorities of this nation. Indigenous affairs was certainly not one of the priorities.

speech.para: This Prime Minister, to give him credit, has been consistent since the day he entered this parliament. On Indigenous issues he has been appalling. He has always taken the low road. History will judge him. At the end of the day, his period in office will be judged. Down the track, in the cold light of day, people will ask, ‘What did this Prime Minister achieve in his period of office?’ He has managed to politicise Indigenous affairs and immigration—two very sensitive areas. Immigration is now a hotbed in the United Kingdom. I see that the Tories want to use it as their way back to government.

This Prime Minister used Indigenous affairs as his way to the Lodge. He was involved as a backbencher in the early debates in the 1970s. He was observed during the debates on the ATSIC legislation to be frothing at the mouth at the dispatch box at the thought of the creation of ATSIC, at the thought of a treaty. With majority control of the Senate, he will have his way. We are told that this government with its ‘practical reconciliation’ for Indigenous affairs will ‘aim to improve the outcomes and opportunities and hopes of Indigenous people in areas of health, education and employment’—and the press release and the press conference went on and on.

Words are cheap. There are people of goodwill on both sides of this House, and expertise in this area does not lie on one side of the House or the other. But this is an issue that requires, over time, bipartisan support. No organisation, no group in the community could survive the attacks that ATSIC has had to put up with over the last nine years. ATSIC was not perfect, but it has been blamed in the Indigenous area for too long for things for which it was not responsible. The government to which I belonged, the Keating government, took health away from ATSIC in the early 1990s. What are the current health statistics? Twenty-four per cent of Aboriginal men will reach the age of 65, and 35 per cent of Aboriginal women will reach the age of 65, and the great tragedy is that many in the community blame ATSIC for those figures. It is not ATSIC’s fault. It is our fault as a parliament, both Labor governments and Liberal governments, because we have not come together to tackle what is a serious problem in relation to our Indigenous Australians, our First Australians, the most disadvantaged section of our community.

We have played the blame game. Make no mistake about it: there are many people on my side of the House who will rejoice at the demise of ATSIC. It did not enjoy support right across the Labor Party, and it has not from its inception. The consultation that took place produced compromise. The model was compromised in the Senate because the government did not have control. ATSIC in 1990 was the beginning; it should have been improved upon. When you look at its budget, you can see that most of it was CDEP, Work for the Dole that originated under Malcolm Fraser back in 1977, and the Community Housing and Infrastructure Program. Many of these programs were subject to audit after audit, including the legal services, and most came through with flying colours. Not all of them were perfect, but the first act of this government in its first budget was to bring in a $470 million cut that decimated some organisations and had an impact on training and bringing Aboriginal people through to administer these programs.

Frankly I am not in favour of the missionary approach. I am not here to save Aboriginal people. I do not know what is best for them. When I was the shadow Aboriginal affairs spokesman, from 1996 to 2000, the best job I have held in this place, it was a great learning experience for me. I worked with Aboriginal people. The solution lies with Aboriginal people. We should be there working with them, not attacking them. I think that ATSIC has had some colourful characters over the years, and it has suited this government and others to concentrate on the individuals not the organisation. Meanwhile the Department of Defence can slip through an estimates hearing with a $500 million overrun. The truth is that there is a double standard on both sides of the House. The argument is that you cannot trust Aboriginal people with money, and we heard that in relation to the previous speaker. But you can go to audit report after audit report. Indeed the last review into ATSIC did not recommend abolition of ATSIC, but the cabinet in considering the report took the abolition route. And it was made easier when the then leader of the Labor Party, Mark Latham, announced that we were going to walk away from ATSIC as well.

For me the good thing is that we will not have anymore, in ATSIC, a whipping boy to blame for the appalling statistics on Indigenous disadvantage. But will we require Aboriginal people to be involved in the solutions in the future? You bet. The attacks on Abstudy by this government have basically meant fewer Aboriginal people coming through to, in effect, be leaders and mentors in their communities. There is a whole series of problems, and the time has come for politicians on both sides to stop using Indigenous affairs to gain political advantage, because we are talking about our fellow Australians here. The repository of all wisdom does not lie on this side. But now, with the demise of ATSIC, this government and future governments, state governments and other bureaucracies will be held to account. The truth is that, in many respects, state governments as well have let the side down.

This is not an easy issue, but there is a mentality that we need to overcome. I did not hand out in the 1967 referendum; it passed me by because I was too young. The Prime Minister did, but what happened? In that referendum 90 per cent of the Australian population voted to give this parliament the constitutional authority to protect and work for Aboriginal people. That was the mandate this parliament received. That was one of the few referendums to succeed with bipartisan support. Malcolm Fraser in his time as Prime Minister had his heart in the right place, to his credit.
