He produced an Aboriginal land rights act, which was not the same as that introduced by the then Whitlam government but it was a long way ahead of any other legislation in its time.

The responsibility lies with us and the time has come to stop blaming the victim. I do not say that ATSIC was perfect but I enjoyed dealing with the commissioners, the regional councils, the committed people who worked out in the regions, and those within the public service and the communities. Of course mistakes were made. Have we learnt from the mistakes? No, we repeat them. And we continue to blame the victims. We continue to seek people within the Indigenous community and blame them for our mistakes.

There is no easy solution to this. I think the demise of ATSIC was inevitable with the election of the Howard government because ATSIC came into being without the support of the conservatives, and all they needed was an excuse. Sadly, in recent times the conservatives have had ample excuses, because it has been easy to get into the blame game. But my understanding is that while some criticisms arose from the audits that occurred, and while there were some arguments about improvements that could have been made, a lot of those organisations were producing results on the ground. ATSIC was value for money and this garbage about most of the money going to administration is just that—complete garbage. I do not intend to get into that debate this evening; the statistics speak for themselves.

There is a similar situation for regional Australians—the farmers. True equality in this country requires differential treatment because we do not come to the table as equals. The problems of regional Australia require special programs for regional Australia. The same applies to Aboriginal Australians. There is nothing wrong with providing intensive assistance to bring people through, but you need a place for them at the table as well.

The only reason that the 1967 referendum included a question on Indigenous people and the census statistics was that the government of the time was looking to retain a seat in Western Australia. So until the 1967 referendum we were more worried about our flora and fauna than our fellow Australians—our First Australians. They were counted in the census only because they were needed by the then Menzies government to retain their representation in the west.

But with the results of that referendum came an obligation on this parliament as a whole. And in the future I want to see an approach by government and opposition which will tackle the hard issues. But I have found that in Indigenous affairs you need Aboriginal people at the table because they are part of the solution. Think about the problems with water and a whole series of other things in remote and regional Australia. Of course ripping-off occurs. Most of the rip-offs—in terms of the stores, the vegetables and a whole series of things in remote Australia that directly impact on health—come from the white communities. A lot of that was not ATSIC’s responsibility, but the responsibility of state and territory governments.

I can recall being on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and talking to Senator Herron, the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, about benchmarking. The benchmarking of the states and territories received unanimous support within the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. Have the states and territories been properly benchmarked in relation to Indigenous affairs? No. I know that Dr Wooldridge, when he was Minister for Health—because of his former position as shadow minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the coalition—made a special effort in relation to Indigenous health in a number of programs. And this parliament should not apologise for that.

The sadness of the situation is that the demise of ATSIC represents a lost opportunity. It is an opportunity that we should have been building on. The only advantage that I see in the demise of ATSIC is that we will no longer have a whipping boy for the failures in Indigenous affairs by governments of all political persuasions. I repeat that I do not know of any organisation, government department or private enterprise that has been audited or scrutinised as much—or that could have withstood the savagery of the political attacks over time—as ATSIC has had to endure.

For a lot of people its demise will come as a relief. ATSIC did not enjoy a lot of support from some Aboriginal people. A lot of Aboriginal people were critics of it. It was quite easy to criticise it because it never had sufficient money to administer programs effectively in the areas for which it had responsibility. To overcome the backlog in Indigenous housing requires some $2 billion. Who is going to fund that? Which government has the courage to give $200 million, let alone $2 billion, to overcome the problems in Indigenous housing? Yet the Community Housing and Infrastructure Program was a ripper of a program in that regard. My understanding is that, in all the auditing that went on in relation to that program, it was never faulted.

In a lot of respects there was value for money but there were plenty of mistakes. Well, hallelujah! As I said, the double standard led to many of the mistakes being magnified. My view is this: if there was criminal behaviour, people should have been prosecuted. But do not blame people because we did not facilitate the training or adequately resource them to administer the services that were needed for their communities. For too long we sat silent when the health statistics were quoted, and did not stand up and say, ‘In 1994 we took responsibility for health away from ATSIC. That’s not ATSIC’s fault; it’s ours.’ And both sides were guilty of that silence, because it was a convenient alibi.

I am one who is genuinely sad at the demise of ATSIC. But that is life. Let us move on. If the government think that they are going to get away with their mainstreaming and assimilation in Indigenous affairs, they are wrong. History has proven that that does not work. What we need is a new partnership, one that can take us forward but one that involves Aboriginal people. That is why it is sad that the government are rejecting the Labor Party’s amendments to do with an extension—from my point of view, an even greater extension—of the regional councils. I do not see anything wrong with electing representatives of Indigenous Australians to speak to and deal with government on their behalf. Local councils are elected to deal with state and federal governments in relation to funding or whatever.

How do you pick an Indigenous person and say, ‘They’re the one to speak on behalf of Indigenous people’? They are a very diverse community. They are not united, as we are not united, but the problem is that their divisions are magnified by the ignorance and prejudice in our community. What worries me is that in the last decade we have not gone forward; we have gone backwards. If the 1967 referendum were held today, it would be lost. That is where we have come to. That is the legacy of the modern generation which includes both Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians. We have to overcome that, because the statistics are appalling and Third World on every indicator. But tonight we can rejoice because ATSIC is no longer able to be blamed. To me that is the one positive out of this grubby legislation, which has taken nine years to come to fruition. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —With a background as a hospital medical officer, then as a child health researcher in remote Australia, as a community eye registrar and most recently as a consultant working for the very organisation we debate tonight, I am sure I speak on behalf of others in this House when I say that I have never walked in the shoes of the many people who are Indigenous Australians. I have not experienced what it must be like to have seniors from my family leave for weeks in hospital and come home in coffins, nor seen babies struggling with completely avoidable diseases, nor had hopes dashed of either a traditional life or a meaningful job, living in the miasma of alcohol and physical abuse that we see in many communities. But I have sat in a CDEP office and worked with incredibly dedicated ATSIC people. I have seen places with no bookkeeping skills and no operating statements that one can understand or decipher. I have seen free flights taken without being accounted for and have seen money being skimmed and disappearing while the kids run crazy, everything is broken and everything is really crook.

speech.para: Tonight, as my first words about Indigenous affairs, I acknowledge Bessie Dixon and Teresa Mathews, who have given their lives to Indigenous affairs and their communities. Having worked with them, I know that there has been a culture of blame and victimisation often combined with poor services. I know that this talk tonight must seem to them like posturing to find a solution. But I would say to both Bessie and Teresa that these sweeping reforms are absolutely necessary and the record spending is the true indication of a practical commitment to making things different. The $2.9 billion spent last year is a far cry from what we saw a decade ago. The money spent today on health in Indigenous Australia is more than that spent in 1994, 1995 and 1996 added together and corrected for inflation. I think many here would agree that ATSIC really was beginning to have very little practical impact on policy development, despite the work of hundreds and thousands of really dedicated people doing everything they could over those 16 years.

I do not believe the CDEP program was producing the really meaningful jobs for which we were hoping. The Business Development Program had a list as long as my arm of failed enterprises, and the number of Indigenous Australians voting in ATSIC elections was down to just 20 per cent. Even when it had the chance, long after this government came to power, the opportunities were not taken to find meaningful solutions and come up with advocacy and policy development in the upper echelons of ATSIC. It was, of course, entirely captured by conflict and eventually by public squabbles and the erosion of public confidence.

There were regional plans that simply never hit the ground. From Urapuntja to Yuendumu, the benefits of having these layers within ATSIC were not being felt, nor was it a representative body because of the low level of voting. What is being proposed as a replacement to ATSIC is far from that. With the abolition of ATSIC, the National Indigenous Council is not intended to be a long-term replacement. Those who are within it are not individuals who are completely fawning, sycophantic and compliant; they are people with free minds, big ideas and bold intentions. I hope their ideas are heard and we hope that a bipartisan approach is taken.

In the past, Indigenous communities have had to struggle and shop around, deal with multiple levels of government and try to take advantage of programs while they could, and the whole time they were not really assisted with the complexities of dealing with government. I am glad that today, although it has been lost in this debate, both federal and state governments are working together and with local communities in the whole-of-government enterprise, and the Council of Australian Governments are guiding that enterprise. I believe communities have ideas and it is through that engagement that we will see success. That is why, while I acknowledge the fantastic work of individuals within ATSIC, I believe the organisation had to go and that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2005 must be passed.

I do want to say just a few words about the opposition’s reflections upon milestones. The opposition have profited for many years in the comfort of those comparisons that benchmarks are not changing. And never have they been glued to anything as much as they have been to life expectancy figures. Surely it must be clear to everyone that you cannot begin to look at what affects life expectancy and you cannot begin to count life expectancy until people pass away. The life expectancy figures reflect the health and living conditions over 50 or 60 years; and, long after things start getting better in Aboriginal Australia, life expectancy figures will remain quite static. If you are serious about finding a figure that does not represent what is happening on the ground, then you will grasp at life expectancy figures.

There are plenty of opportunities to find great stories and improvements. It would be far wiser to focus on figures like those for infant mortality which have improved substantially—the mortality has dropped—in comparison with non-Indigenous Australia. These are the early signs and the evidence of progress in health delivery. I mention this because the opposition has often painted itself as having the warm embrace for Indigenous Australia, whether you travel from the universities to the health clinics and all the way out to the community centres. I have always had that slight concern that the warmth of the embrace is not really reflected in the ideas and proposals that are put together. It has always been that little bit easier to simply be critical of what is happening at the moment. I believe that because you often see these comparisons with New Zealand and Canada and Indigenous populations in the United States that have absolutely no relevance to the gains and the work that is being done on the ground in Indigenous Australia. It is a completely different situation from those we see in other countries where they have indigenous populations.

The disappointing thing tonight is that our 10 minutes each have been wasted by members on the other side, who really did have an opportunity to put together and propose some bold ideas and some alternatives. Instead we have seen what I suspect is a rather feeble amendment about retaining regional councils. It does surprise me that that would be an amendment proposed by the opposition. It surprises me that perhaps they have listened to a few members of regional councils who may have wandered in and asked the opposition to support such an amendment and they have thought, ‘We can’t really disagree with the bill, so we’ll put this up as an alternative and see whether it can consume little bit more time.’ What, fundamentally, is the difference between ATSIC and 35 little ATSICs in the form of regional councils?

In the end, there was not the engagement between government and community. The only way to get the ideas coming up from the community—quite apart from building capacity within those populations themselves—was to reduce the capacity required to engage government. That is what the whole-of-government approach is about. We can work for generations to build capacity, but isn’t it time we looked to ourselves to find ways of more effectively and efficiently delivering services and making them available, ensuring that the rubber hits the ground where it counts? That is what the whole-of-government approach is about, and I have great confidence in that process, having seen it from its evolution a few years ago.

I was often inspired to send people who wanted to know more about this debate to the opposition’s web site for a more fulsome expansion on what they might propose as an alternative to ATSIC. So it surprised me that, on going there, you would find just eight lines. The first line said: ‘Committed to reconciliation.’ The second line said: ‘An apology to the stolen generation.’ The third line said: ‘Replace ATSIC with an elected representative body’—of which there is no further definition or discussion. Then there were two final bullet points on service provision in health and education, and then something about ‘broad participation based on genuine reciprocity of obligations, where governments as well as citizens fulfil their responsibilities’. Apart from a bit of cutting and pasting about mutual obligation—taken from our side of the House; we had been talking about this for a decade—I do not see anything there of comfort to Indigenous Australians who look for an alternative vision.

We have heard tonight from opposition members that the National Indigenous Council cannot speak on behalf of Indigenous Australians. But I question seriously whether ATSIC ever did. The government reforms have shifted the emphasis from that very Western style regional council to working with local communities directly. I think that is an important advance that has been a little bit ignored tonight. No one size fits all, and there is an incredible heterogeneity in Indigenous communities from the urban to the remote, but I believe such bodies should be formed by Indigenous leaders themselves coming from the grassroots. With time, those leaders will emerge. It will take time and participation. Money is not the only input that needs to be measured. At the moment I believe there are no good ideas coming from the other side. We have heard three speakers; I would like to hear something put up as an alternative from the next four.

No-one could have been clearer than the member for Banks, who has deep experience in the area of Indigenous affairs, I have to acknowledge. But, again, there was a floundering around somewhat stratospheric and nebulous ideas about shifting blame. If ATSIC was something to get rid of it would have happened long ago. But, no, it was given an enormous amount of rope, an enormous amount of faith and an enormous amount of resources. I think there should be great concern in the Indigenous communities around Australia, whether they are remote or urban, about the lack of ideas from the opposition tonight. It has been a perfect time to step into this chamber and hold above your heads a piece of paper saying: ‘This is our vision’—as an alternative to ATSIC or to whatever structure is being proposed. If there is an emotional attachment to ATSIC, which I suspect is exemplified in the words of the member for Banks—I do not hear it from the other members—then say it. Let us hear those alternatives. Let us have the bold ideas, the big proposals. Let us seek concrete ideas to make a difference to the work and lives of people like Bessie Dixon and Teresa Mathews, to people who, from the Western Desert through to the central Northern Territory, have given their lives to helping their young ones, as paediatric workers, to have a future of health and achievement that they can look forward to.

Few will mourn the passing of ATSIC, but I think the Indigenous people of this country have a right to expect a whole lot more from the debate from those opposite tonight. They should expect meaningful alternatives and ideas but, so far, I think many of those have been glaringly vacant. I was not here for some of the early debate on this bill, but I think it is a great disappointment that tonight all we are hearing is some slightly sentimental and melancholic comment about the organisation but no meaningful alternative.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)—Order! It being 9 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to talk about the impact of the interest rate rise in my part of Sydney, an impact which has been largely underestimated by various comments made by those responsible in the government. Make no mistake about it: the people of my part of Sydney, through most of Sydney and I daresay through most of Australia believe, and have every reason to believe, that they were promised a rise such as we have just had would not occur.
—Rubbish.

—I challenge the minister opposite, if he thinks it is rubbish, to send a direct mail to every one of his constituents saying, ‘I want to let you know we never promised interest rates wouldn’t go up.’
—Happy to do that. Happy to tell them about 17 per cent under Labor as well.
—Order!

—That is what I would suggest the minister do. Part of the lack of understanding from the government—we just had the exact example there from the minister—is the failure to understand where interest rates are at relative to where debt levels are now at.
—We know where they were at under you before.
—The minister will desist from interjecting.

—The issue is always going to be not what the rate figure is but the relationship of debt to income. With the radical growth in credit, the property boom and radical changes in property prices, what it now costs a young family to get into the housing market compared to what it cost before means that you do not get to the real fear level at 17 per cent; you get to it well before then. It will be at 8½ per cent that most of my friends will not own their homes anymore—well before any figures like 17 per cent. I do not imagine there will be many homeowners left at all with those sorts of figures. So the idea that those figures are a threat is the government wanting to say, ‘The entire economy would collapse and then the interest rates would continue going up.’

speech.para: Every time the government talks about 17 per cent, it fails to acknowledge the danger to household income of 8½ per cent and the absolute financial strain and loss of property and loss of home ownership that people would face should interest rates get to nine per cent. What has happened to home ownership is something that I saw from the day that we got into our own mortgage. Within six months of moving to our part of Sydney, we were living in a home we could no longer afford to buy. I found a situation where friend after friend my own age was not able to purchase a home in the area where they grew up because property prices had gone to more than double what they could afford. They had found themselves moving out into areas of Western Sydney and south-west Sydney to get homes, then to find that the property prices there had similarly ballooned.

Add that to what has happened to credit card debt and compare interest rates of many years ago: not only are we now in a different international climate but, more importantly, we are in a different climate of household debt. Anyone who wants to claim a ministerial role in the government of Australia who does not understand the impact of household debt and how sensitive you can be to interest rates rises does not understand what goes on in the part of Sydney I come from. They do not understand what happens in south-western Sydney; they do not understand the area that is going to the by-election on Saturday; and, they do not understand what has also happened in parts of Melbourne or Brisbane. And you do not have to be in the major capital centres to find a radical rise in household debt.

We hear about average mortgages, but what is more important than that is average new mortgages. For young families trying to get into property and their own home ownership, it does not matter, when you average it out, what is happening to people in their late fifties who are at the very end of a loan. What matters to those young families is the new mortgage size. The average for new mortgages in Sydney is now $427,500 and a quarter of a per cent interest rate rise on that amount is $69 a month. So you can imagine how many young families are finding themselves—if they want to live anywhere near their extended family—on mortgages way in excess of that average. Then add to that what has happened to the other parts of household debt—(Time expired)

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: —I wanted to take the opportunity this evening to talk about developments in relation to water conservation within the electorate of Flinders and within Victoria generally. I want to make reference to three things. The first is dramatic progress in the fight to clean up and to resolve the issue of the Gunnamatta outfall.

speech.para: What has happened in Victoria is that after stalling for some years the Victorian government has finally agreed to make progress towards the clean-up of Gunnamatta outfall. Gunnamatta outfall produces 150 gigalitres, or 150 billion litres, of water each year which is pumped out as secondary level treated sewage straight onto Victoria’s beaches at Gunnamatta. It has a health effect; it has a dramatic environmental effect and it is an enormous waste of resources. One hundred and fifty gigalitres, or 150 billion litres, of water is water which could be used for agriculture and industry and in so doing take pressure off our dams and our rivers in the Thomson, Latrobe, Gippsland and Macalister systems.

On that basis what has occurred is a great step forward. With the National Water Initiative, the federal government had provided an opportunity and a way out for Victoria. It has provided a means by which the Victorian government will ultimately be able to address the problem of Gunnamatta, the shameful waste of water, the dramatic impact on our coastline and to deal with this in a way which has an impact for future generations.

Last week the Victorian government agreed to sign the National Water Initiative to embrace the Australian Water Fund and to give itself access to the $2 billion which the Commonwealth is providing, $1.6 billion of that being for infrastructure. That is a tremendous step forward. That means in particular that they will be able to examine the proposal for a pipeline for the recycled water, transferring it from the eastern treatment plant at Carrum Downs and using it for the Gippsland pulp, power and paper mills and stations in a way which will take the pressure off the water being drawn from the Thomson, Latrobe and Macalister systems and allow for environmental flows. It will reuse the water and will also significantly take away the impact of dumping sewage off Victoria’s coastline. That is a tremendous step forward. I welcome the agreement from the Victorian government and I thank the Commonwealth for the step that it has taken on that.

In relation to water infrastructure, there is an even bigger challenge within Australia. Melbourne Water, Sydney Water and a number of other major organisations around the country with the responsibility for water are state owned monopoly infrastructures. The problem here is that there is a lack of competition and a lack of openness to private capital in relation to the disposal of water. Why does this matter? It matters because, for example, in the case of Sydney there are 400 billion litres of sewage treated only to a primary stage and flushed between 2,000 and 3,700 metres offshore. Private sector money is willing to come in and have an impact by upgrading the quality of the treatment to ensure that the water is reused, overcoming the problems of health, environment and resource wastage. But under the current monopoly system they are being prevented from doing so. In that situation we need to bust open these monopolies in a way which will provide opportunities for private sector capital. Significantly, it will clean up the water resources and Sydney beaches and allow water to be reused. It will protect the Warragamba Dam and the Shoalhaven and, above all else, allow for Sydney’s water security over a long-term period.

talk.start.para: —I rise to draw to the attention of the House an issue I believe is of real interest to the people of Kingsford Smith and the community at large. As the House would be aware, Australians are living longer and healthier lives than ever before. Currently, life expectancy is 82 for men and 87 for women. While this is great news for the majority of us, it can be the cause of much anxiety for many as they struggle to plan for their own retirement or tackle the question of how to care for aged parents or grandparents.

speech.para: When we talk about ageing there is a range of factors to bear in mind: sufficiency of retirement incomes, availability of paid employment, family care, education, social participation and volunteering. These factors contribute to a quality of life that all Australians, regardless of age, deserve. Australia’s population is ageing rapidly. The Future ageing report released by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Health and Ageing, which will be debated in the House, has found that there are around five people of working age supporting each person aged over 65. It is called the ‘potential support rate’. When you consider the majority of our population are between the ages of 40 and 65 it begs the question of what governments, and this government, are doing to ensure that investment in quality infrastructure as it pertains to an ageing population has been implemented and that forward planning exceeds the span of a four-year election cycle.

It is important to understand that illness and frailty are not inevitable parts of ageing. As Australia’s demographic changes so must the broader perceptions we have of older people. Too often we see negative images of ageing and the ageing process reinforcing myths and allowing discrimination. The media regularly portray health and longevity in terms of young people full of life, failing to show the same verve and activity in older folk, some of whom I am sure we know. So it is critical to recognise that only a minority of older people, for example, move into residential aged care facilities. That is why our focus must be broader than this stereotype of ‘old people in nursing homes’.

Labor’s policies have always been about ensuring dignity and security. Not surprisingly, we are critical of the government for their lack of infrastructure and long-term work force planning, their lack of investment in research and, most critically, their mixed record of collaboration with state and territory governments, stakeholders, researchers and carers. This effective collaboration is much needed to enhance the quality of life of this growing group of Australians. Our aged population deserves access to fair and equitable aged care facilities that encourage them to lead a fulfilling and healthy life well into their retirement, without fear of budget cuts to the pension or lack of adequate health care facilities.

In my electorate of Kingsford Smith alone, some 12,727 people receive the age pension, the majority of whom continue to live in their own home. The rising cost of living means that our ageing population faces an uncertain financial future. That is why I believe it is important to actively support people’s choice to continue living in their own home and to ensure that the necessary services are provided for them in that place. Whilst Labor welcomes the current injection of funds by the government in this area, we are conscious of the lack of planning in the area of service quality and provision since its first election term.

The National Aged Care Alliance has released a set of recommendations for strengthening the government agenda for aged care. My colleague Senator Jan McLucas, the shadow minister for ageing, disabilities and carers, has been active in the development of policies that ensure the longevity of aged care for future generations. The recommendations of the alliance focus on the need for fairness and equity in funding, the linking of aged care and health needs and, more importantly, the need for long-term high-quality service planning for the aged. I can assure the House that I will be actively working in my electorate to ensure that these recommendations are not ignored but are made to stick.

Quality of life is the key factor in this issue of an ageing Australian population. If we are to live longer then it must be satisfying and as enjoyable as possible. The community at large should be encouraged to make the most of the talents, wisdom and experience of those who reach a ripe old age. Older Australians with these qualities in abundance will contribute significantly to community volunteer projects, the arts and many other aspects of our life. Our seniors have so much to give; let us make sure we support them.

talk.start.para: —In this adjournment debate tonight I wish to highlight two issues which are of great concern to me. Firstly, I would like to place on record my very great admiration for the parliamentary reporting staff and Hansard but, in doing so, to express my concern at the adoption of the Macquarie Dictionary a number of years ago as the pre-eminent source of spelling for words used in the parliament. I think it is unfortunate that the thought police, or the word nazis, seem to have introduced spellings which most Australians would find to be utterly bizarre as the preferred spelling of words used in the parliamentary Hansard. I have not got time tonight to outline everything, but most people would accept that the Oxford Dictionary really is the pre-eminent English dictionary, yet a group of academics at Macquarie University decided to attempt to turn Australian English into a dialect and in doing so brought forward some most peculiar spellings.

speech.para: In my own office I prevent my staff from using American spellings. I prefer the more traditional English spellings because—let us face it—we are a derivative society and mostly in Australia we tend to use the more traditional spellings over American spellings. It is therefore a matter of grave concern to me that the parliamentary Hansard seems to have been hijacked by the thought police who have imposed American spellings on the Australian Hansard. I recall that a number of years ago I used the word ‘amok’ in a speech, yet Hansard insisted on using a spelling I had never seen before—‘amuck’. I spoke to about 20 people and I asked them, ‘How on earth do you spell the word “amok”?’ and every single person said ‘amok’, yet I was unable to convince the parliamentary Hansard staff to spell the word correctly. Hansard now assures me that they have adopted ‘amok’ instead of ‘amuck’. There are numerous other examples. People who want to turn our language into a dialect insist on, for instance, the American spelling of ‘program’, rather than ‘programme’. And I think that Mr Speaker ought to look at this matter because, as Australians, we are proud to be Australians, but I think that we ought not to accept that we are part of a cultural cringe.

I understand that John Campbell, when he was the Principal Parliamentary Reporter, a number of years ago decided in his wisdom to adopt the Macquarie Dictionary. To my knowledge, there was no debate in the parliament. It means that the way we spell words was hijacked by one person in the parliamentary Hansard. I would like to appeal to the current chief of the reporting staff to give some flexibility: if members want to use traditional spellings as opposed to the spellings imposed by the word nazis at Hansard, then maybe members ought to be able to write to Hansard to request that their speeches be written in a traditional form rather than the form dictated by the Macquarie Dictionary.

I also want to highlight at this stage a very important conference which is taking place on the Sunshine Coast in relation to the national sea change phenomenon. I have received a letter from the Mayor of Maroochy Shire, Councillor Joe Natoli, to advise me that the National Sea Change Summit will take place at Coolum in July this year. This is intended as a briefing session for members of the House of Representatives whose electorates cover coastal growth areas. A task force has been established as the national body to represent the interests of coastal councils and communities experiencing the effects of rapid population and tourism growth. Formed last year, it currently represents more than 50 member councils from all Australian states and the total population of the areas covered by these councils is approximately four million residents.

The Sunshine Coast is one of the fastest growing areas in Australia. People like to move from the rustbelt areas represented by many members opposite to the sunbelt, and we are very pleased to have them, but we have particular challenges relating to infrastructure and the need for government support, so I am hoping that this national sea change summit will be well attended. It is very important that we get the message across to governments, both state and federal, that as coastal communities growing rapidly we have particular needs. The Sunshine Coast is a wonderful part of the world in which to live, and it is a great privilege to represent it. Many people move to our area and we need particular government assistance. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I note at the outset that I am approached about many refugee cases and a large number of those I find unconvincing. However, tonight I wish to raise the situation of Ardeshir Gholipour, a detainee at Baxter who arrived in this country in the year 2000. I have recently been advised by an officer of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, as a result of correspondence to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, that decision making by the department is ‘objective and fair’. Well that might be; however, I believe this particular case does stand out for action by the minister. I am especially impressed that International PEN, a representative body of writers around the world, is supporting this particular case. This indicates something because it is an organisation that does not readily lend its name to every Tom, Dick and Harry who puts their name forward.

speech.para: The situation in Iran is that after the Islamic revolution of 1979 there was severe repression by the newly instigated theocratic regime. Many had hoped that, with the disappearance of the shah’s regime and the repressive tactics of the SAVAK secret police, the situation would improve. They were sorely wrong. Since then we have had a regime which, by any international standards, is amongst the most repressive in the world. The 1997 election of Mohammed Khatami seemed to hold out the hope of improvements. However, his endeavours have been clearly stymied by the continued power of the religious leadership in the country.

As for Mr Gholipour, I am especially impressed that Faraj Sarkoohi, a person who was adopted by Germany in 1998 after his flight as a refugee and who is active in International PEN and its German branch, has testified in correspondence that Mr Gholipour did in fact assist him whilst he was jailed by ensuring that his documentary evidence of his incarceration was circulated throughout Iran in the magazine Khaber Nemeh. Similarly, the brother of Pirooz Faghhai Davani—who was murdered by the Iranian regime—who is also a resident of Germany, has testified in support of Mr Gholipour for his now deceased brother. There are clearly indications from Iranian progressive forces and people of international repute that Mr Gholipour has indeed the track record that he has claimed.

The situation in Iran, of course, is that from the late 1990s the murder of prominent writers and of journalists throughout the country has taken place. Newspapers have systematically been closed down. As late as December 2004, Sarah Leah Whitson, the executive director of the Middle East and North Africa division of Human Rights Watch, spoke of the secret torture sites and the torture of internet journalists and community activists. It is a reality that still occurs daily in Iran. It is not a year ago; it is not two years ago; it is a continuing situation. With his track record of being a stern critic of the regime and having been jailed before his flight in 2000, Mr Gholipour would indeed be in great danger if he were to be returned to Iran. I note that in this particular case he has obtained the support of significant management figures at the Baxter detention centre. This, again, is unusual—that a detainee would actually have letters of support on the public record from people in those kinds of positions. His artistic skills have also been put on the record and could be beneficial to this country.

The situation, as I say, continues to be deplorable in Iran and it gives strong grounds for the minister to reconsider this case. I do not want to hear about the fact that, under ministerial discretion, this case has been decided properly. We know that ministers in this portfolio have been inventive in the way they have been able to read the rules of ministerial discretion to allow a significant number of people to pass through the system. The deplorably low level of support by the current minister, Minister McGauran, of only four per cent approvals—contrasting Minister Vanstone’s rate of 40 per cent—is indicative of the problems in the system at the moment. Mr Gholipour has a history of involvement in human rights issues in Iran. He has engendered widespread support in the Australian community. He has been supported, as I indicated earlier, by people in management positions at Baxter detention centre and, indeed, his case has been taken up by an organisation of international repute that does not give its name readily or easily to every person in the world with an asylum claim. I again ask the minister to consider this case very seriously under ministerial discretion.

talk.start.para: —The spirit of Kokoda has been dormant for far too long and that has been recognised on the Gold Coast by the formation of the Kokoda Challenge Association, which was launched recently at Nerang RSL. The formation of this association has been led by Mr Doug Henderson with the advice and help of Mr Charlie Lynn—a man whose passion for Kokoda is truly inspiring. Charlie visited the Gold Coast last year and, at a meeting organised by Doug at Nerang RSL, told all in attendance about the history of Kokoda and the sacrifices of some astonishing young Aussies to hold back the invading Japanese. It was a story of endurance, sacrifice, courage and mateship. In the main, our young men were untrained and inexperienced as the majority of our regular forces were fighting overseas in Europe and the Middle East.

speech.para: The young men sent to Kokoda were outnumbered. They were under-resourced and fighting in terrain that was inhospitable. They were supported along the 96-kilometre track by the fuzzy wuzzy angels—natives of New Guinea who helped carry urgent supplies of food and ammunition along the track for our young Aussie soldiers. The temperatures were often freezing in the Owen Stanley Range. The fuzzy wuzzy angels were not equipped for the weather. They had no footwear or blankets and had only grains of rice to sustain them. They even often shared the rice with wounded Australians whom they stretchered to safety.

Kokoda is a story like no other, but unfortunately it is a story that Australians do not know. It is time the youth of this country were educated about the story—about the sacrifices and ultimate victories. It is time this story was taught in a meaningful way in our education system. Today the jungle has reclaimed the battle sites which are etched in the minds of our ageing diggers. Along the Kokoda Track, rusting armaments, shallow graves, empty weapon pits and spent ammunition cartridges are haunting reminders of a desperate campaign fought on our very doorstep during the darkest days of the war in the Pacific just over 60 years ago.

The Kokoda challenge will be a tough team event with four members on each team. They must complete a 96-kilomentre trek, which is the same distance as the Kokoda Track. It is to be completed within 39 hours, which symbolises the 39th Militia Battalion, the first of our Australian troops to arrive at Kokoda, on 15 July 1942. The inaugural event will be held over the weekend of 16 and 17 July in the Gold Coast hinterland. The event will be a fundraising effort to assist Charlie Lynn and the Kokoda Track Foundation in their endeavours to promote and support the education, health and general wellbeing of the surviving fuzzy wuzzy angels and their descendants still living along the track.

The program for the event has been structured so that our Gold Coast youth can experience the real spirit and soul of our amazing country and her forefathers. It challenges our youth to seize the day, to accept the problems at hand, to adapt, and to envisage and implement future strategies of success in their own lives. The Kokoda youth leadership challenge, in partnership with the Returned Services League, service clubs and local secondary schools, will identify students that are determined as suitable candidates for the challenge. We all believe that the youth of our country hold the answers to our future success as a nation. Like our forefathers, the students participating in the walk will rise to the challenges they will experience over the two days.

Charlie Lynn shared with us his own personal experiences and those of a number of young troubled and negative people with whom he has walked the Kokoda Track. It certainly was a story of endurance, sacrifice, courage and mateship. The trek was difficult. There were enormous challenges for many of the young people, but with Charlie’s encouragement and commitment to each of them they finished the walk.

The Mayor of Gold Coast City Council, Ron Clarke MBE—one of Australia’s former great athletes—is patron of our Kokoda Challenge Association. Our Governor-General, Major General Michael Jeffery, and his wife will attend the inaugural dinner following the two-day event. The association is extremely grateful for the commitment of both these distinguished gentleman in supporting our inaugural challenge. Of course, thanks must go to the schools involved, to the local bushwalking group, who have assisted in marking out the track, to the first aid officers and to the local RSL clubs, who have embraced this event with enthusiasm and commitment. We believe that the Kokoda youth leadership challenge will be an enduring legacy to the spirit of Australia that was born at Gallipoli and held fast at Kokoda. I am personally very proud to be part of this challenge and wish all those involved every success with the inaugural event in July this year.

talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for government schools is not reported at the level of detail requested. Australian Government General Recurrent Grants for government schools are provided to the government education authority in each State or Territory, on the basis of total enrolments. The State or Territory determines where the grants are used. Payments to individual schools are not recorded.

The Department of Education, Science and Training only provides postcode detail for General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools, Capital Grants to both government and non-government schools, and Flagpole funding for both government and non-government schools. No Capital Grants funding was provided to government schools in the identified postcodes in 2004. Flagpole funding totalling $1,185 was provided to one government school in the identified postcodes in 2004.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for non-government schools cannot be reported at the level of detail requested. Funding from Australian Government programmes that can be reported at this level of detail for non-government schools in the identified postcodes totalled $39,403,283. This amount comprises $39,347,283 from the General Recurrent Grants programme and $56,000 from the Capital Grants programme. No Flagpole funding was provided in 2004 to non-government schools in the identified postcodes.

item.label: (c)

The purpose of the Australian Government Capital Grants is to assist in the provision of school facilities, particularly in ways that contribute most to raising the overall level of educational achievement of Australian school students.

The purpose of Australian Government General Recurrent Grants is to help schools with the recurrent cost of school education so that they can offer students educational directed towards the achievement of the Australian Government’s priorities for schooling.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 8 February 2005:

item.para: What representations has the Government recently made at an international level in respect of the banning of anti-vehicle land mines.
Does Australia intend to participate in the development of international measures to ban anti-vehicle land mines; if so, what will be the nature of Australia’s involvement in that campaign.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Downer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: None.

There are no international measures involving states currently under development to ban anti-vehicle mines (AVMs). The majority of countries do not support a complete ban on AVMs. Australia strongly supports efforts by states parties to the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons (CCW) to build a consensus that would allow the commencement of negotiations for a protocol to the CCW restricting the use of AVMs. Australia is a co-sponsor of the “30-nation proposal”, proposed at CCW meetings, which aims to make all AVMs detectable and ensure that all remotely-delivered mines self-destruct/self-neutralise and self-deactivate.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 8 February 2005:

item.para: Were any Australian officials deployed in Papua New Guinea (PNG) agencies during 2003-2004 as part of the Enhanced Cooperation Package between Australia and PNG; if so, how many?

Will any Australian officials be deployed in PNG agencies during 2004-2005 as part of the Enhanced Cooperation Package; if so, (a) how many, (b) when, (c) to which PNG agencies in which PNG locations, and (d) for how long?

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Downer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Eight Australian officials were deployed to PNG in financial year 2003-2004 as part of the Enhanced Cooperation Program (ECP). No Assisting Australian Police (AAP) were deployed to PNG during this period.
Yes

item.label: (a)
item.para: It is planned that 58 officials and 210 police will be deployed during the financial year 2004-2005, in addition to those deployed since 2003-2004.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Of the 32 officials already deployed this financial year, 10 were deployed on 16 August 2004, four were deployed on 22 September 2004, eight were deployed on 25 October 2004, two were deployed on 29 November 2004 and eight were deployed on 14 February 2005.

The first AAP deployment of 18 Australian police and one liaison official from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade arrived in PNG on 29 August 2004. Since then, AAP deployments have taken place on 26 September, 24 October, 21 November, 19 December, 20 January 2005 and 17 February.
Further deployments of officials and police will occur over the next few months.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The PNG Department of the Prime Minister and National Executive Council, the PNG Justice and Attorney-General’s Department, the PNG Department of Personnel Management, the PNG Treasury, the PNG Finance Department, the PNG Department of Foreign Affairs and Immigration, the PNG Internal Revenue Commission, the PNG Department of Defence, the PNG Civil Aviation Authority, the PNG Auditor General’s office, the PNG Department of Transport, the National Judicial Service, the National Judicial Staff Services, the Department of Correctional Services, and, possibly, the Department of National Planing and Regional Development. All these officials are located in Port Moresby.

AAP work in the Royal PNG Constabulary. At present eighteen AAP are assigned to Bougainville, and 117 are placed in Port Moresby. It is proposed that the AAP will gradually move out to Lae, Mt Hagen and the Highlands Highway.

item.label: (d)
item.para: The duration of individual officials’ deployments vary and are specified in their Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) with their Australian parent agency. AAP deployees may elect to deploy for either 60, 80 or 100 weeks. Typically, deployments of both officials and AAP range from one to two years. The ECP Treaty provides for the program to run for a total of five years.
